div.p: THE Fate of CAPUA. A TRAGEDY. As it is Acted at the THEATRE In Lincolns-Inn-Fields. BY His MAJESTY's Servants. Written by Thomas Southerne.

q.p: Caetera, neque temporum ſunt, neque aetatum omnium, neque locorum: Haec ſtudia adoleſcentiam alunt, ſenectutem oblectant, ſecundas res ornant, adverſis perfugium, ac ſolatium praebent: Delectant domi, non impediunt foris: Pernoctant nobiſcum, peregrinantur, ruſticantur.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.byline: Written by the Honourable Charles Boyle, Eſq;
div.l: OUR Bard reſolv'd to quit this wicked Town,
And all Poetick Offices lay down:
But the weak Brother was drawn in again,
And a caſt Miſtreſs tempted him to Sin.
Thus many a cautious Gallant in this Throng,
May wed, when old, whom they debauch'd when young.
Thus the repenting fair Ones vow in vain
From Cards, from Love, from Scandal to refrain,
For Eaſter over, they relapſe again.
To write well's hard: But I appeal to y'all,
Is't not much harder not to write at all?
Some Men muſt write, for Writing's their Diſeaſe,
And every Poet's ſure one Man to pleaſe.
Some medling Coxcombs, rather than ſit ſtill,
And perfectly do nothing, muſt do ill.
Some are with buſie Dulneſs ſo o're-run,
They ſeem deſign'd by Heav'n to teaze the Town,
Yet when theſe Fools have ſpawn'd ſome ſickly Play,
We have ſo many greater Fools than they,
They'll pack a crowded Audience the third Day.
This Poet has no ſly inveigling Arts,
He'll try to gain, but he'll not ſteal your Hearts.
His Muſe is ruſtick, and perhaps too plain,
The Men of ſqueamiſh Taſtes to entertain:
Who none but Dutcheſſes will daign to toaſt,
And Favours only from front Boxes boaſt.
That's all Grimace: When Appetites are good,
Be the Dreſs courſe, the Air and Manners rude,
You can take up with wholſom Fleſh, and Blood.
But he deſpairs of pleaſing all the Nation,
'Tis ſo debauch'd with Whims of Reformation.
H' has done his beſt: Here is no wanton Scene
To give the wicked, Joy, the godly, Spleen.
Not one poor bawdy Jeſt ſhall dare appear,
For now the batter'd, Veteran Strumpets here
Pretend at leaſt to bring a modeſt Ear.
Here is ſome Love, 'tis true, ſome Noiſe, ſome War,
Enough to pleaſe the Belles, the Beaux to ſcare.
Some buſtling Patriots too, ſome Rabble-rout,
And Senators of the weak ſide thrown out.
But in all this, here's nothing can offend,
Nothing to loſe one ancient midnight Friend:
He hopes then, when his Cauſe comes on, they'll all attend.
Let Critick Foes remember 'tis paſt Lent,
And all good Chriſtians Curſes then were ſpent.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: POets fine Titles for themſelves may find:
I think 'em the Fool-mongers of Mankind.
The charitable Quacks indeed pretend,
They trade in Fools, only thoſe Fools to mend.
Yet they wou'd ſcarce the nauſeous Task endure,
But that, like Bedlam Doctors, they are ſure
To get, by ſhowing Fools they cannot cure.
Equal in this, all Plays muſt be confeſt;
Fool is the fav'rite Diſh of the whole Feaſt.
In Farce, the Wit's a Fool, or Fool's a Wit.
In Comedy, the Beau pretends a right.
But Tragick Writers ſtill agree to plot
The greateſt Heroe, for the greateſt Sot.
Our Bard t' indulge your Taſte with vaſt delight,
Serv'd up a Senate full of Fools to Night:
Same buſtled hard for Hannibal, and ſome
Wou'd venture all the Brains they had for Rome.
Thus fighting Fools ſupport ambitious Knaves:
Whoe're prevail'd, the Capuans ſtill were Slaves.
Our pair of Friends ſhine far above the reſt,
With double ſhare of Fool, and Heroe bleſt.
Our Lover wou'd not tempt the Lady's Honour;
Yet had he boldly puſht, and fairly won her,
You'll all allow, he wou'd leſs harm have done her.
Joys well contriv'd are had at eaſier price.
Thank Heav'n our Britiſh Friends are not ſo nice.
Our moſt important Fool is ſtill behind:
The Man was marry'd, Sirs, and ſick in mind.
'Twas a meer whim of Honour coſt his Life.
The ſqueamiſh Capuan wou'd not ſhare his Wife.
Why Wives are Wives: And he that will be billing,
Muſt not think Cuckoldom deſerves a killing.
What if the gentle Creature had been kiſſing,
Nothing the good Man marry'd for, was miſſing.
Beſides the Rights of Ladies ſacred are:
He ſhou'd have been content with Neighbours Fare.
But ſhe, by her coy Gallant's Crime, was good,
And was not won, becauſe ſhe was not woo'd.
Had he the ſecret of his Birth-right known,
'Tis odds the faithful Annals wou'd have ſhown,
The Wives of half this Race, more luckie than his own.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: THIS only I wou'd offer to you more:
My known Alliances, and kindred Blood,
By intercourſe of Marriages with Rome,
Cementing long the Honour of my Houſe,
With all the intereſts of that glorious State,
May well proteſt for me, that I adviſe
Abandoning the Romans to their Fate,
As neceſſary to avert our own.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.l: To avert our own!

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: At leaſt you'l join with me,
It may be needful to advance our own.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.l: Ay, there I cloſe with you when you ſpeak plain.
The Romans Loſs at Cannae ſhows it ſelf
Plainly in this, that their Confederates,
Who had ſtood Ages faſt and firm for Rome,
From that moſt dreadful Day began to fail;
Deſerting her in abſolute Deſpair
Of her loſt Empire, not to be reſtor'd.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.l: You have a Liſt of all the ſeveral States,
People, and Cities that are faln away
From Rome to the Carthaginians:
Let it be read—

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: It has been read already.
Their Number and Example ſhou'd adviſe
Their Neighbours, who intend to follow 'em
As we muſt do, to follow cheerfully;
To jump into our Reſolutions;
What muſt be done, to have it frankly done;
To make a merit of our Forwardneſs;
And not diſgrace the Service we intend,
By cold Debates, Indifference and Delay.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: Our Rabble are in barefac'd Mutiny.

sp.speaker: 3 Sen.
sp.p: And have declar'd themſelves for Hannibal.

div.stage: Shouts in ſeveral quarters of the City.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.p: The noiſe comes this way now.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: 'Tis every where.

sp.l: Make way for Decius Magius.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: I thought he had giv'n o're the Common-wealth.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I thought ſo too: But there is nothing certain:
I was in hopes I might have ſtaid at home:
But when a City is in general Flame,
Cripples will find their Legs to cry out Fire.
Age has not much to loſe: But I am come
To awake, to rouze, and warn you of your Ruin.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: What is this Ruin, Decius Magius?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: In ſuch an honourable Argument,
As yours may be, in the Tarentine War,
A Peace from Pyrrhus was propos'd with Rome:
The Queſtion almoſt was reſolv'd for Pyrrhus:
When Appius, as we have it on Record,
Aged and blind, diſabled long before
To the State's Service, and the publick Cares,
Was led into the Senate, and inſpir'd
By Indignation, and his Country's Cauſe,
Sway'd the Debate, never to make a Peace
With any foreign Foe in Italy.
I come by his Example: He was happy
In his Succeſs; and ſo may I be bleſt,
So may I thrive to Day, as this great Cauſe
That lies before you now is of more worth,
Of weightier worth, and threatning Conſequence.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: A long Preamble: What will be the Tale?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: They ſay, you are upon deſerting Rome,
And joyning Hannibal: I have a Voice
Before it comes to that, and muſt be heard.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: We have all Voices for our Countries good.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Our Country's Honour is her chiefeſt good.
Can we forget what Rome has been to us?
A foſtering Neighbour of our Infant State:
A kind Rejoycer in our Growth and Strength:
Ever a Friend: And in Adverſity,
(As we have taſted of that bitter Cup,
Now ſwill'd in Pleaſures to the giddy Brim
Of drunken Riot, and Forgetfulneſs:)
In our bad Days, I ſay, ſhe ſtill has been
A Comforter, a Parent, and Protector.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Well, Decius Magius, had you minded us,
If we had been inclining to forget
What, as Allies and Friends, we owe to Rome.
But Vibius Virius, you our Legate were,
Commiſſion'd to Rome's Conſul: You can ſay—

sp.speaker: Vib.
sp.l: That we have paid all our Reſpects of Grief;
Condol'd their Dire Misfortunes, offering
Supplies of all things wanting to their Wars:
This in the general Name of Capua:
But Cordials to the Dead are ſo apply'd:
Fortune has left 'em nothing to ſupply.
The Roman Legions, Enſigns, Horſe, and Arms,
Men, Money, and Proviſions, routed, ſpoil'd,
All in the Day of Cannae were deſtroy'd,
Or on the Morrow's Plunder of both Camps.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: So that 'tis not enough to aid 'em now:
If you do any thing you muſt reſolve
To undertake their War with Hannibal.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: And can you undertake a worthier Cauſe?
Is there a worthier, than a ſocial War?
Our Anceſtors compell'd within theſe Walls,
No longer able to Defend the City,
The Samnites, Cidicines, inveſting us,
Sinking in Ruin, who upheld us then?
Who, but the Romans, cou'd have ſav'd us then?
They took us trembling to Protection:
Suſtain'd a Warr for near a Hundred Years,
With Fortune often varying the Event,
Dreadful to Italy, againſt the Samnites,
Which they begun, and carry'd on for us:
And is there nothing to be done for them?

sp.speaker: 4. Sen.
sp.l: Why, that is true; if we cou'd do it,
Without an injury to our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Have we not always been affianc'd Friends?
Our Laws, our Cuſtoms, Couſtitutions
Allmoſt a-kin, and, as our Marriages,
Mingled, and wove into our mutual Weal?
The Citizens of Rome, and Capua,
Enjoying common rights of Burgheſie,
Speak us indeed one People in two States.
So that whatever miſchiefs fall on them,
Betide us too; and we muſt ſtand oblig'd,
By all the Bonds of honeſt Intereſt,
To ſave a Country, equal to us both.

sp.speaker: 5 Sen.
sp.p: That I don't ſo well underſtand neither.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: This is no. Samnite, no Hetrurian War;
Where if one loſe a Neighbour State muſt win;
And tho' the Empire ſhou'd be torn from Rome,
It ſtill remains with us in Italy.
We ſhall not find it ſo with Foreigners:
The Carthaginians are theſe Foreigners:
The Carthaginians are our Enemies—

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Hold, have a care—

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I will, to ſpeak the truth;
And ſay again they are our Enemies:
Rivals of Empire, in this ſecond War:
And therefore to be thought the common Foes
Of Rome, of Capua, and of Italy.

sp.speaker: 4 Sen.
sp.p: Urg'd home, and boldly.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: O! let us pay the debt of Glory now!
Tho' Rome be drooping, we may raiſe her Head.
Our Forces are unbroken, freſh, entire:
Full thirty thouſand Foot, four thouſand Horſe,
Upon our Muſters in Campania:
Money, Munitions, and Proviſions,
With the proud Train and Equipage of War,
Martiall'd, and ready Harneſs'd for the Field,
All high of Heart, and full of able Proof.
If then our Friendſhip, and Fidelity,
Anſwer the firmneſs of our Strength and Power,
Hannibal will not perceive his Victory;
No, nor the Romans feel their ſore defeat.

sp.speaker: 3 Sen.
sp.p: Here comes another Meſſenger.

sp.speaker: 4 Sen.
sp.p: The news?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: If I had breath, it is not to be told.
The madding Rabble have at laſt poſſeſt
The ſober part, the peaceful Citizens,
Infected by their fury, are in Arms;
And Capua now is but one Multitude.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: There is no time for Foreign Argument
Of right and juſt; of future good or ill:
Since what we have to fear, is preſent now,
Imminent, and breaking on our Heads at home.

div.l: Make way—good Marius Bloſius take your ſeat:
We know you've done the beſt you can for us:
When you're collected, you will tell us all.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Diſorders, Tumults, and Confuſions,
Raging with Horror up and down our Streets,
Had ſpent themſelves in Oppoſition
Of their contending Parties; there we hop'd
The Uproar wou'd have end: But now they join,
Rabble and Citizens, in horrid League,
And all combin'd in Violence, reſolve
On Miſchiefs more premeditate and bold.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.p: Reſolve on what?

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: What Miſchiefs are reſolv'd?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: All who are Romans found in Capua,
(As we have Families tranſplanted here)
Tho' in the ſervice of our State employ'd,
Or in their private Callings, they have ſeiz'd—

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: How! ſeiz'd!

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Men, Women, Children, hudled in the Rout,
Without diſtinction hurry'd and ſhut up,
Under the name of Safety, in our Baths,
The publick Baths, where choak'd with Heat and Smoak,
Their ſtrugling Souls muſt wretchedly expire,
If timely not ſet free.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: If this goes on
Ruin muſt follow: I will ſpare no Pains
For their Deliverance.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.p: Wretched indeed!

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.l: Barbarous and cruel to our worſt of Foes,
Without a Name to our Allies and Friends!

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: No Friendſhip, no Alliance after this.
What they have done, is a ſad Argument
They will do more to carry to their ends.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Nay, there is more in hand, and to be fear'd,
Directed this way too: For, One and all,
They cry, the Senate's Councils are too ſlow,
That they intend to come and quicken 'em—

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.p: The Gods forbid!

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: Avert this Danger, Heav'n!

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: But that we ſhall no longer buy and ſell
Their Intereſts, with our mercenary Tongues:
That we but hold the Government in truſt
For them, they all have Law enough for that,
They ſay, they can recall it when they pleaſe.
They'l do their Work themſelves; they'l have no more
To do with us; we never did 'em good,
Before this time; and now againſt our will;
Affording 'em ſuch juſt occaſion
To throw us off, Senate and Tyranny.

sp.speaker: 3 Sen.
sp.p: Heav'n grant it go no farther.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: But I fear—

sp.speaker: 3 Sen.
sp.l: They bear us ancient hate on former Scores:
And what the Priviledge of ſuch lawleſs Times,
May ſet 'em on to act, is to be fear'd.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Nay, what portends the worſt, and threatens moſt:
This head-long Rout, this lew'd ungover'd Crew,
Is Captain'd, headed, and led on by ſome,
The nobleſt Blood, and foremoſt of our Youth:
Who ne're will think their ſervices well pay'd,
But at the price of univerſal Change.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.p: They're at our Doors.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: What will become of us!

sp.speaker: Meſ.
sp.l: Fly, fly you Senators of Capua:
There is no ſafety for you, but in Flight:
The People are determin'd in your Doom,
And now come on to Execution:
They've vow'd to Murder you, and ſo give up
The Common-wealth void of all Government
To Hannibal, and Carthaginian Power,
To model new, and ſtamp what form he pleaſe:
As the beſt Sacrifice, the juſteſt Means,
To attone his wrath, and puniſh your delay.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Let us not ſtand confounded in our fears:
Gaping on one another, as relief,
Without our care, wou'd drop into our Mouths.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: What can we do?

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.p: We wou'd do any thing.

sp.speaker: 3 Sen.
sp.p: No God to pity us!

sp.speaker: 4 Sen.
sp.l: Pacuvius, you have been the Peoples Friend;
Wou'd we had all.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.l: Ay, good Pacuvius,
You might do much, would you appear for us.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: I had ſome credit with 'em: what 'tis now—

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: They will hear you.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: I cannot promiſe that.
But what I can, I will: perhaps I may
Do more than you expect— but then you muſt
Give up your Faith entire to what I do;
Lay by your Fewds, and Factions in the Senate;
Submitting all to my Direction.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Diſpoſe of all, ſo you deliver us.

div.head: SCENE, The Outſide of the Palace.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Shut up the Gates; none to paſs in or out,
But by my Orders: if a Senator
Eſcapes your Guard, you anſwer with your lives
To our great Lords the People.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Why, here's a Lord indeed.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: He does not think himſelf too great
To be the Peoples Friend.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: No, no, Lord Pacuvius has been always our Friend:
And we will be his upon Occaſion: for he ſhall find himſelf,
Within this half hour, the only Senator unhang'd in Capua.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: My Country-men; my fellow Citizens!
'Tis in your Power now to revenge your ſelves
On this deteſted Senate, juſtly fal'n
Under your Sentence; odious grown to all,
Who love the People, or the Common-wealth.
I offer you a full and ſafe Revenge,
A free Revenge, nothing to Interrupt,
But you may do your Work with decency:
No Tumult for one Senator to ſcape in.
Without the danger of invading 'em
In their particular Houſes, which wou'd be
Defended by their Friends, Clients, and Slaves,
I have 'em here, defenceleſs, and alone,
Impriſon'd in the Palace. Say the word
What ſhall be done with 'em?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Come, come, open the Gates,
We'll quickly diſpoſe of 'em.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: Ay, ay, we are Men of Expedition,
And ſo they ſhall find us, to their Coſt:
Every Man take his Senator; We'll hang 'em
Upon the Battlements of the Palace, for a ſtinking
Example to all Common-wealths.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Hold you, hold you, I don't like hanging:
There's a great deal to be done in a handſom Execution.

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.p: Look you, my Maſters, I am but a plain Man to ſee
sp.l: to, as a body may ſay, but I can ſpeak my Mind without being
askt, as ſoon as thoſe that are wiſer: Look you, time is precious,
and we have a great deal to do with it; make as ſhort
work as you can, I adviſe; ev'n cut their Throats, and
there's an end on't.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Cutting of Throats is but a
Slovenly way of doing Juſtice:
I am for doing things decently, Neighbours, and I believe
I have hit it: This is not an ordinary Day with us, you know,
Why then let's make a Holy-day of it indeed;
Set the Palace a Fire about the Senators Ears,
And there's a Bonfire to our Holy-day.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed, a Bonfire, a Bonfire.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: It was the very thing I was thinking of—

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Why very well.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Nay, it is excellent,
To have the old Drones ſmother'd in their Hives.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: No more to be ſaid, Boys;
About it inſtantly, my Lads.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: We are all in a mind once in our Lives.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Fire the Palace, down with it, Fire the Palace.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: And yet what has this noble building done?
A publick Ornament, a reverend Pile,
That has ſtood Ages— but if you pleaſe to think
It has ſtood long enough, why, down with it;
Who ſhall find fault? It is the Common-wealths,
The People's, and you may diſpoſe your own.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: How's that? The Palace Ours!
Let's hear him a little upon that Subject.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: The Senators! blow them up in a Blaze:
You will miſs nothing of 'em, but their Beards:
Or if you ſhould, they cheaply are ſupply'd.
But if the Senate Houſe be laid in Aſhes,
Who ſhall repair the Ruine?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: At a time when Capua ſtands the Rival of great Rome,
You would not ſtrip her of her Palaces,
To leave her naked to her Neighbours ſcorn?

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: No, no, We don't deſire that neither.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: This venerable Structure may ſtand up
With our moſt celebrated publick Domes,
Sacred and Common, Temples, Theatres,
And all our numerous progeny of Art,
The Monuments of famous Anceſtry,
That ſpeak as loud for us, as Rome's for her.
And wou'd you throw it down?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: If you repent, when it is down, who builds it up again?
The publick Purſe alone, the common Stock
(The Citizens freeborn Inheritance)

l.hi: Whoever does the miſchief, pays for all.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: If it be ſo, my Maſters!

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: 'Tis as he ſays, Man, and the caſe is quite alter'd.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Why, my Lord, we're at a loſs here
For want of Employment.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: You have ſav'd the Building, 'tis true,
And we thank you for't: But the Senators—

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ay, ay, the Senators, the Senators—

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: I am their Goaler ſtill, to anſwer their forth-coming,
When you pleaſe, and to promote the Juſtice you intend,
Since you are not agreed among your ſelves,
I do propoſe to bring each Senator
Upon the tryal of his ſingle Merit,
To ſtand or fall, juſt as his Cauſe deſerves:
Your ſelves to be the Judges.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Why there you have hit it, my Lord?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Every honeſt Man muſt be
Of your Lordſhip's Mind.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Your ſelves to be the Judges!
Mark you that?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Well, my Lord, Pray proceed in your own Method:
We know you're a Friend to us,
We'll be govern'd by you.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Then in the firſt place, I wou'd have you
So govern your Anger, that your Anger get
Not the upper hand of your Int'reſt and Safety.
For I ſuppoſe your Hatred extends to theſe Senators only;
You like the Conſtitution well enough—

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: My Lord, that's more than we can ſay
With a ſafe Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: What! Not like a Senate!

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: To tell you the truth, we don't approve of th' Order,
And wou'd baniſh it the City, if we cou'd.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: You muſt have a Government among you.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: You muſt have a Senate; a Senate is
But the great Council of a free People,
And that's for your Good you muſt own.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Well, if we muſt have a Senate—

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Why, that's well ſaid:
Then in order to a Reformation, my Maſters,
There are two things that call upon you at the ſame time;
The diſſolving your old Senate,
And chuſing a new one in the room.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Why, there I grant you,
A Senate of our own chuſing we may like.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: We'll chuſe a Senate, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: I will ſummon the Senators,
One after another, to appear before you:
What you judge of 'em ſhall be executed:
I will only gather your Voices.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: This is method now.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Unbar the Gates, and bid the Senators
Prepare themſelves to appear upon their Names.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Ay, this is doing buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: But one thing you muſt promiſe me, my Friends,
To puniſh none, however criminal,
Before you chuſe an able, honeſt Man
Into his place, as a new Senator.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: That's fair on every ſide.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Here is a Roll, agree among your ſelves
Whom to cite firſt—
This Day muſt crown our hopes.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: The Deputies are return'd from Hannibal.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Let 'em be ready, I ſhall want 'em ſtraight.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: Let's ſee, let's ſee, where ſhall we begin,
At the top or the bottom.

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.l: Hold you, hold you; Titus Didius here; begin at him:
I hapned to get a Slave of his with Child,
And he made me marry her, for which
I ſhou'd be very glad to ſee him hang'd.

sp.speaker: 4 Cit.
sp.l: Make 'em into Lots, I ſay,
And let 'em be drawn fairly.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ay, ay, every Man take his chance.

div.stage: They are buſied in making the Lots, while Pacuvius and Virginius ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: O that Perolla, my degenerate Son,
Wou'd follow thy Ambition; but he pules,
And Conſcience bound in ſuch a Cauſe as this,
The Cauſe of Empire, baſely ſtands for Rome
Againſt his Country, and his Father's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: That Decius Magius has infected him.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: My old Oppoſer ſtill.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: He has been every where among the Crowd,
To ſpread the Poyſon of his Politicks:
But we had dos'd 'em with our Antidotes;
Timely preventing all the giddy turns,
That might have hapned to that ſickly State;
Confirm'd the crazy Conſtitution
Of their weak, wavering Minds; and now we have
Scatter'd, diſpers'd the Faction, and the Cauſe,
Quite routed him, and his malignity.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: So that the People all ſtand ſound for us.
But do not truſt 'em with themſelves too long:
They will relapſe into their natural fears,
And cool, without your Fire to keep 'em warm.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Theſe you'll take care of: I have other parties
To Head, and bring up on occaſion.

div.stage: The Citizens come forward, one having drawn a Lot.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: So, ſo, without favour, or affection, now open it—

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Who have you drawn?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Rutilius Lupus there, let him appear.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Ay, ay, let him appear,
And be hang'd for his pains, I ſay.

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.p: Ay, ſo ſay I.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: And all of us.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: Here, here, he comes.
He has always been an Enemy to the People.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: And now we'll quit ſcores with him.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Well, he is doom'd: You do expel him firſt
The Senate— but before his Puniſhment,
You muſt elect a New one in his Room.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ay, ay, that's quickly done.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: He may paſs on, we'll talk with him anon.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Who ſhall we chuſe Neighbours?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: Let's lay our Heads together,
And do it to purpoſe, once in our Lives.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Why, ay, who ſhall we chuſe?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Let me ſee—

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Some body that deſerves very well of the Commons.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: That's to be ſure.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: One that is in the intereſt of his Country;
And, if poſſible, will continue ſo
In ſpight of Preferment —

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: That's the Man, that's the Man.

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.p: Who, who?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: Nay, good troth, I can't tell;
We han't found him yet.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: He muſt be one, we have nothing to ſay againſt—

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.p: Ay, marry, who may that be?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: One who wonnot forget his Benefactors,
The People that rais'd him.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: A very good Quality indeed;
Now name the Man that owns it, and I give him my Voice.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Nay, I name no Body.

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.l: Name no Body! what! We muſt name ſome Body:
Come, I'le name one —Cecilius Nepos.—

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Cecilius Nepos! there's a Man indeed!

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.p: What do ye think of him?

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: We don't think of him.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: Stay, ſtay, the Senators are call'd Fathers,
You know —

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: Why, in that ſenſe he may be qualify'd:
And thou doſt honeſtly to ſet him up.
For he is naturally thy Senator,
Being the Father of thy Family.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: No, no, we'll Father our Children without him,
If we can, with our Wives leave, we'll none of him.
Set up another.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: That's worſe and worſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: What ſhall we do with him?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: He knows nothing of the matter.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: When he ſhows any management
In his private Affairs, we may
Begin to think of him for the Publick:
In the mean time, let him play the fool
At his own expence, and in private;
As he uſes to do.

sp.speaker: 4 Cit.
sp.p: Mamellius then.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Mamellius! who is he?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: He is one, that was ſqueez'd out of the Neceſſities of the Government; that has made a hard ſhift to get a mighty Eſtate, by the common Calamities; a plaguy rich Fellow.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Rich! as a dunghil may be,
By a Congregation of Filth and Villany.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: Wou'd he were to be ſo well beſtow'd;
Carry'd out by a common conſent, for he's a Nuſance
As he is, and ſpread abroad for the enriching the Publick.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: O, ho, I know him, a Viper, that has eaten thro' the Bowels of his Country, in hopes of coming to the Head on't: But I hope he will return as he came, and go out at the Tail.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Well, Furius Philus.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: He's too proud for us.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Let him pay his debts.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: He pays no Body, as 'tis.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: And you wou'd give him a priviledge
To ruine his Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Well, are you agreed?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Agreed, my Lord, there's nothing to agree upon:
When we come to particulars, 'tis only to find fault:
Men are but men; and, new or old,
The Senate's the ſame.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Why do you diſſolve this then?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: We don't diſſolve it.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: No, no, we don't diſſolve it.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: And for this Reaſon, Neighbours, to carry home to your Wives, to ſtop their Mouths withal; becauſe the Evils that we are beſt acquainted with, are always the eaſieſt to be born.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Marry I think ſo too.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: And all of us.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: Therefore I am for ſetting
The Senators at Liberty.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ſet 'em at Liberty.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.p: Provided they joyn with us in this buſineſs.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Heartily, and ſpeedily, or we ſhall viſit 'em again.
And ſo you may tell 'em, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: I wonnot fail.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.l: Pacuvius! O! what Honours are thy due!
Statues, and Temples, thou Deliverer!

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.l: We cannot ſpeak our humble thanks too low,
In the deep ſenſe of our acknowledgments.

sp.speaker: 3 Sen.
sp.p: Thou haſt ſav'd our Lives, diſpoſe of them and us—

sp.speaker: 4 Sen.
sp.p: Our Fortunes, Friends, and deareſt Intereſts.

sp.speaker: 1. Sen.
sp.p: Command in all, for we owe all to thee.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: I have been the happy Inſtrument indeed
To ſerve the Senate—

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: Nay, to ſave the State.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: And I am nobly pay'd in the good work.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.p: The People tho' won't be ſo ſatisfi'd.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: No, they are obſtinate upon their Terms,
You muſt comply with 'em.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: We are agreed in every Article for Hannibal.

sp.speaker: 3 Sen.
sp.p: And wou'd declare our ſelves, did not our Friends—

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Under the Roman Arms in Cicily—

sp.speaker: 3 Sen.
sp.l: As Hoſtages for our Fidelity,
Withhold us, till we can provide for them.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: That fear was urg'd before; but you ſhall have
It fully anſwer'd by our Deputies:
I ſee they are return'd.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: O! welcome, welcome!

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: What have you done for us with Hannibal?

sp.speaker: Dep.
sp.l: We bring moſt advantageous Terms of Peace.
Theſe the Conditions; the laſt of which
Removes the preſent fear, and does provide
Expreſly for our Friends in Cicily.

sp.speaker: 3 Sen.
sp.p: Let that be read.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Nay, read 'em not in parts.

sp.speaker: Dep.
sp.l: He offers you three Hundred Roman Knights,
Which you ſhall chuſe out of his Priſoners,
To give the Romans, in a fair Exchange,
For our Campanian Youth in Arms with them.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.l: He has hit upon the ſole Expedient,
To enſure the Lives and Safety of our Friends.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: He offers more than we cou'd ask of him.

sp.speaker: Dep.
sp.p: You'll find him in all points as generous.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Now are you ſatisfy'd?

sp.speaker: 3 Sen.
sp.p: We ask no more.

sp.speaker: Dep.
sp.l: In the juſt confidence of profer'd Love,
He comes himſelf, the Hoſtage of his Faith,
To Capua.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: So my Advices ſay, but mention not the time.

sp.speaker: Dep.
sp.p: He comes this Day: He's on his March already.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.p: Let us prepare for his Reception.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Summon the People to the Forum then,
And let the Articles be read to 'em:
So hand in hand we ſhall proceed in Love,
And act unenvy'd for our Country's good.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Pacuvius! You have done moſt worthily,
Saving the Senate: Wou'd you wou'd employ
Your Intereſt with the People always ſo.
The wretched Romans wanted ſuch a Friend:
I had no Pow'r: But Death has ſet 'em free.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.p: Dead! Are they dead?
sp.stage: The Senators go out one after another, and leave him alone.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: All periſht in the Baths.
And they are left behind, to bluſh in Blood
For this Day's Treaſon, who encourag'd it:
It muſt be anſwer'd for to Gods and Men,
And Capua rue it in her Sons unborn;
An impious City of devoted Crimes!
The Vengeance will fall heavy, and, I fear,
Fall wide enough, ev'n to involve us all.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.p: Alas! We are not guilty of their Death.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: But mourn alike with you the People's Rage.

sp.speaker: 3 Sen.
sp.p: What cou'd we do?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: What are you doing now?
Where are you going? Do you leave me too?
But you indeed have left me long ago.
Your Steps have err'd long from the track of Truth,
And are not worth an honeſt Man's purſuit:
But I will follow. If I can't prevent,
I may proteſt againſt their Practices:
That's in my Pow'r: That will exempt me from
The general Guilt, and juſtifie my Fame:
Let me ſecure my Innocence, and then
Death to an Old Man cannot come too ſoon.

div.head: SCENE, Virginius's Houſe.
div.stage: Favonia at work with her Women.

lg.head: A Song written by a Lady.

l.hi: The Miſtreſs of it knows it well.
Good Teeth, and Hair, a ſmiling Grace,
Can't give Perfection to a Face:
Not yielding Lips, or wiſhing Eyes:
But ſhe is handſom who denies.

lg.head: A Song in Anſwer written by a Gentleman.
lg.l: WHAT Beauty is, let Strephon tell,

l.hi: Who oft has try'd it, knows it well:
Not all the Wonders of a Face,
Where Nature triumphs in each Grace,
Not Snowy Breaſts, thro' which is ſeen
The purple Flood that boils within,
Not Lips, when Wit with eaſe beguiles,

lg.l: Whilſt playſom Cupids dance in Smiles,

l.hi: Not Youth, not Shape, not Air, not Eyes,
She only charms me who complies.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Among your Women in your Huſwifry!
Fye, 'tis a Profanation of the Day,
Sacred, and ſet apart from common uſe,
And dedicated to the publick Joy.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: The publick Joy, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: The general Joy:
In which I have ſecur'd a part for thee,
A liberal ſhare for my Favonia.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: May I ſecure my private Peace at home:
And for the publick, let the Joy, and Grief,
Fall to their different Fates, who riſe and fall.
The State does not concern a Woman's Care:
Yet, Sir, I thank you for remembring me.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Doſt thou! Well, there's ſomething ev'n in that;
There is a kind of Gratitude in Thanks,
Tho' it be barren, and bring forth but Words.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: I do not underſtand —

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Thou doſt not; true:
And that's the very root of my Complaint,
That any thing relating to my Love
Shou'd ſtill be ſtrange, not underſtood by thee.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: My Lord —

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: O! thou art cold in my reception,
Thou can'ſt not think thy ſelf, but thou art cold.
I wou'd have met my Welcome in thy Arms,
My eager Welcome in thy longing Arms,
That ſhou'd have cruſh'd me inward to thy Heart,
Into thy Heart, if it were poſſible,
Throbbing and beating with the Pulſe of Love:
That, that had been a Welcome fit for me;
And a juſt Recompence of all my Pains.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: Indeed, my Lord, I owe you every thing,
In recompence of what you have done for me:
But for your welcome, that you bring along
With you; 'tis yours, as you are Maſter here:
And if I have not ſerv'd it up to you,
As does become the Duty of my place,
With that frank Cheerfulneſs to give content,
Let me not anſwer for my Nature's Faults.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Nay, now thou art too ſerious.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: I am unhappy in the want of all
Thoſe neceſſary, natural Arts to pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Thou art above the little reach of Arts,
And can'ſt want nothing, but the Will, to pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: What is there that I can invite you to,
That you do not diſpoſe of?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Nothing, nothing:
Thou art all mine; and let me tell my Heart,
That hourly grows more covetous of thy Love,
And therefore buſie to torment it ſelf,
Its Fears are vain, and thou art wholy mine.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: I own your Title, and you are the Lord
Of every thing that does belong to me.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Why, what wou'd I have more? There's nothing more.
I do confeſs that I am happier
Than I deſerve to be; much happier:
I commit many Faults, but none to thee.
O! cou'd thy gentleneſs of Soul infuſe
Its Spirit into my Breaſt, to temper mine;
How ſhou'd I then be bleſt! But who can tell?
Perhaps 'tis better order'd as it is.
Indifference wou'd never ſuit my Fate.
My Paſſions are unruly, and ſometimes
Break looſe on my beſt Friends: But then you ſhou'd
Conſider 'em as the effects of Love:
As the effects! Nay, they are Love it ſelf
For Love it ſelf is all the Paſſions,
At leaſt to me: Whether it be Deſire,
Or Hope, or Fear, or Anger, or Revenge,
In all its different Motions, ſtill 'tis Love.
Love, Love! The great Incendiary here!
His Torch ſets all this little World on Fire:
And let it burn, to purifie my flame:
For Life and Love ſhall both burn out together.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, you are ſtay'd for.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: So, ſo, well, I come.
I have forgot my ſelf, my buſineſs too,
With looking on thee. Can'ſt thou tell me, Love,
What 'twas I came about?

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: Buſineſs, you ſay.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I fancy'd I had mighty buſineſs here:
But now I find 'twas but a fond pretence
To come and viſit thee.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: You're always kind.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: The hurry and the ſtruggle of the Day,
You were Inform'd in by my Meſſengers.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: They hourly brought me the particulars.
And there are ſomethings done, which I could wiſh—

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Things which I thought I cou'd not have allow'd.
And, but to raiſe thy Fortune, never wou'd—

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: Pray heav'n they do not overturn it quite.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: But they muſt paſs with others in the Crowd,
There will be miſchief in confuſion:
I had forgot: Thou art a Stranger ſtill
To the ſad News: Thy Rival is no more.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: My Rival!

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Yes, thy Rival in my heart:
You had it all between you, Wife and Friend:
Junius, that Friend is dead.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: Dead! Is he dead?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: He fell at Canna: Had he been alive,
And ſtill a Roman in his intereſt;
I never cou'd have been a Foe to Rome.
I have an hour of grief to Dedicate—
But this is not the time. I'm call'd upon.
Hanibal comes, the glorious Hannibal.
His entry will be moſt Magnificent,
And will reward your Curioſity.
I will provide you Place, and ſend for you.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: What? what is there that I can want on Earth,
To fill the meaſure of my happineſs?
Why am I not contented with my Lot?
So kind a Husband falls not to the fate
Of every Wife: All that he ſays, and does,
All his deſigns are working ſtill for me:
And yet I cannot thank him, as I ought.
Not but I ever had a dutious Senſe—
But that is not the payment of the Heart.
He asks my Love, and not my Gratitude.
And why is that deny'd? O! Junius!
But thou art dead, and I may name thee now.
I made it Criminal to pronounce his Name,
Avoiding every way all news of him,
Endeavouring to forget him, if I cou'd.
But Oh! the torment, and the rack of Soul!
To keep our thoughts for ever on the bent
Upon themſelves, ſtill labouring to forget,
What, by the labour, we remember more.
Why didſt thou come between him, and my Heart?
Why rather did my Husband place thee there,
By bringing thee into the Family?
I ſaw no danger, till it was too late.
But what have I not done, and ſuffer'd too,
To drive thee thence, to make Virginius room?
I have maintain'd an everlaſting War
Within this Breaſt, ſtill fighting on his ſide:
Have ſummon'd all my ſuccours to my Aid;
My Native Powers, and the Confederate Force
Of Reaſon, Duty, Virtue; nay brought down
The Woman's laſt Reſerve of all, my Fame:
Weak Aids, alas! againſt the Tyrant Love.
But he's depos'd, and Death has ſet me free:
A greater Tyrant gives me Liberty.

div.head: SCENE I. The Forum.
div.stage: Decius Magius with Perolla, and two or three of his Clients among the Citizens.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: A Garriſon in Capua! O! prevent,
Reſiſt their Entrance, block their Paſſage up.
Remember Pyrrhus, and the Tarentines;
His inſolent Rule, and their ſubjected State.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: They are already enter'd.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Let 'em not poſſeſs themſelves,
Expel 'em, drive 'em out:
Or if, by a brave memorable Blow,
You wou'd redeem your baſeneſs to your Friends,
Cut 'em in pieces, and compound with Rome.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: They are not of your Party. They fall off.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Old honeſty is us'd to ſtand alone.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Here comes my Father.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Good young Man retire:
I may ſay ſomething that you wou'd not hear.

div.stage: Pacuvius with the Senators in their Robes, croſſing the Stage.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Widen our Gates; let our encircling Walls
Sink in the Earth, that nothing may appear,
Ev'n in a ſeeming Oppoſition,
To ſtand againſt the conquering Hannibal:
The Conqueror of Rome, but Capua's Friend.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.l: We need no Ramparts now, no Bulwarks, Walls,
We're ſtrongly Fortify'd in Hannibal.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: What are the Forces that he brings along?
Not only Affricans, but Nations drawn
From the extreameſt limits of the Earth;
Hercules's Pillars, and the Ocean's Bounds:
Who have no knowledge of Humanity:
And but in Humane Speech differ from Beaſts:
Brutal, and Bloody: but their Leader has
Advanc'd their natural Barbarity:
Erecting Monſtrous Bridges of the Dead,
On Human Bodies urging his proud way—

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: Nay, Decius Magius.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: And, as an abſolute Maſter of the Warr,
Defying Famaine in his horrid Camp,
Has taught 'em to devour the Fleſh of Men.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.p: Now, Magius, you grow Dangerous indeed.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Are theſe to be our Friends? theſe our Allies?
Who that is but a Son of Italy,
Can ſee, and ſuffer ſuch deteſted Slaves,
Whom but to touch is a Pollution;
Such obſcene Villains to become our Lords?
What! ſhall we turn a Province to their Power?
Who wou'd depend on Affrick for her ſmiles,
That looks upon the fair-fac'd Italy?
Can you conſent, that ſhe ſhou'd fall at laſt;
A ſober Matron, and unſully'd yet,
With all her Graces, to the ſwarthy ſpoil
Of hot Numidians, and luſt-burnt Moors?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: We'll hear no more. Perolla, if thou art a Son of mine,
Leave him, and follow me. Forward, my Lords.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I have done with Hannibal.
And now, Pacuvius, a word to thee.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I know my Duty here, and will withdraw
From what I fear, a Father's Infamy.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: This you muſt anſwer.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: To the Gods, and Men,
I'le anſwer it; wou'd thou cou'dſt do as much,
For what thou haſt done.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: I have ſerv'd the Common-wealth—

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Thou haſt ſerved thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: And 'tis thy Envy rails.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: O! that there was no juſter cauſe to ſpeak!
But ſure there's not ſo reprobate a Wretch,
To envy thee the ruin of thy Country.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: The ruin of thy peeviſhneſs and pride.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: That Fame unenvi'd ſhall be wholly thine.
Thou canſt not as a free-born Citizen,
But underſtand, that true proſperity
Lives in a common ſhare of liberty:
Not in the plunder of our Neighbours rights.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Who has invaded 'em?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Thou wouldſt be firſt:
And would thou hadſt been ſo, in dignity
Of honeſt deeds: but that was not enough.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: I find I am arraign'd: What was there more?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Thou haſt long practiſed on the Government:
Poys'ning its wholeſome Conſtitution,
By lawleſs, bold experiments of power.
And now they are broke out in Tyranny,
To infect the health and life of Liberty.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Becauſe I have appear'd the peoples friend.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Thou did'ſt betray the people to themſelves,
By taking off their ſafe reſtraining Laws:
And then the Senate to the Peoples rage:
That by the credit of redeeming both,
Thou might'ſt betray Us all to Hanibal.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: 'Tis very well; go on; let him go on.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: What is the puny part that thou muſt act
In this poor Farce of thy Ambition?
What will it end in? O! thou would'ſt be fear'd,
Rather than lov'd; thou ſhalt be hated too;
And then what comes of thee? Who can be happy
On ſuch conditions of an anxious Life;
That ev'n his Murd'rer ſhall not only 'ſcape
Unpuniſht, but ſhall be rewarded too?
All good Men will combine againſt thy life:
Tho this may want deſign to lay the Plot;
A ſecond, Courage to attempt the Deed;
Another want an Opportunity;
All will conſent, and wiſh to have it done.
It is enough for gallant Minds to know
How honourable in the enterprize,
How grateful in the general benefit,
How glorious in the Renown and Fame,
It is to kill a Tyrant. Hannibal,
Immur'd in walls of Steel, cannot be ſafe.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: O! he'll take care to ſave himſelf from you.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Where then can'ſt thou from Juſtice hide thy head?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: The Laws are living ſtill, to puniſh ſuch
Licentious tongues.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: By Death, or Baniſhment?
Say which, thou Tyrant; which do'ſt thou pronounce?
Death drives us from the fellowſhip of mankind:
But Baniſhment from only ſuch as thee.
Before I take my Journey, I prefer
Theſe two Petitions to the immortal Gods:
The Firſt, That I may leave my Country free:
The next, Pacuvius, thou wilt joyn me in:
And we will bind all our poſterity
In the ſtrong Charm, as guilty of this Vow:
That all that does belong to thee, and me,
Our Children, Kindred, Family, and Name,
May flouriſh, or decay, may riſe, or rot;
Be bleſt, or curſt, as thou and I deſerve
From Capua, and from the Commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Thou haſt Curſt thy ſelf, and ſo expect thy Fate.

div.stage: Pacuvius goes out with the Senators: Magius remains only with his Clients: Perolla returns to him.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: When I was Young, I fought for Capua,
And wonnot now deſert her, being Old:
But all my bravery is in my Tongue,
I can but talk, and that unminded too.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I fear you'll find you've done and ſaid too much.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: Stand, Decius Magius—

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Well, I am the Man.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: I come from Hannibal, to ſummon you to appear before him.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Tell your Hannibal
His Punick Language is not currant here:
We do not underſtand his ſummoning:
He has no right upon a Capuan:
I am free-born, and therefore wonnot come.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: O Sir, you are undone.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: I think not ſo.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.p: The Snares are ſet, you cannot 'ſcape 'em now.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You are encompaſs'd round with Enemies.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Better encompaſs'd round with Enemies,
Than live to be forſaken of our Friends.
Diſtreſs is Virtue's Opportunity;
We only live, to teach us how to dye.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: What is this Pomp of Hannibal to me?
I cannot loſe my ſelf ev'n in the Crowd;
His coming wou'd be welcome, cou'd it guard
All other Images from entring here.
While I am gazing on the Triumph, one,
Meaning no harm, cries, This is the reward
Of Cannae's Field: I ſtart, and take the hint,
Purſuing it quite through that Scene of Blood,
Till it preſents at laſt my Junius ſlain:
My Junius, O! the guilt of that Surprize!
Why muſt I harbour in my Boſom Thoughts
Thus to ſurprize me to my ſin and ſhame?
I ſhall betray my ſelf in Company,
Therefore moſt fit for me to ſtay at home.
Oh! let the ſteps of Youth be cautious,
How they advance into a dangerous World;
Our Duty only can conduct us ſafe:
Our Paſſions are Seducers: but of all,
The ſtrongeſt, Love: he firſt approaches us,
In childiſh play, wantoning in our Walks,
If heedleſly we wander after him,
As he will pick out all the dancing way,
We're loſt, and hardly to return agen;
We ſhou'd take warning, he is painted blind,
To ſhow us, if we fondly follow him,
The Precipices we may fall into.
Therefore let Virtue take him by the hand,
Directed ſo, he leads to certain joy.

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.p: Is there no more to be ſeen? is the Shew over already? Is this all?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: All, Why, what did you expect?

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.p: Expect, marry, I expected.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: You ſaw Hannibal, did you not?

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I ſaw Hannibal: But, what? I thought he had been half as big as one of his Elephants: Your Heroes, I find, are little more than other Men, when you come near to examine 'em.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: But did you mind his looks?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: How terrible he lookt with that one Eye!

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.p: Very terrible indeed.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: I ſtood by him a good while, and heard all that he ſaid to the Senate when they met him.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: And what, what did he ſay?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Why, he began very civilly, that's the truth on't, and thankt us for preferring his Friendſhip before our Alliance with the Romans.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: And what more?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Why, he aſſur'd us, that Capua ſhould, in a little time, be the Capital City of Italy.

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.p: Ay, marry Sirs.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: And that the Romans themſelves, as well as other People, ſhou'd do Homage to us, and fall under our Government.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Nay, Pacuvius told us as much; that when the War was at an end, and Hannibal the Conqueror, he wou'd carry back his Forces into Afric, and leave us the Empire of Italy. We ſhall all be Great Men.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: But I did not ſo well like the end of his Speech.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: 'Twas all againſt Decius Magius: and truly he came to plain ſpeaking at laſt, and told 'em roundly, He expected they ſhou'd deliver him into his Power.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: And what ſaid the Senators?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Why truly, not much to the purpoſe at that time: Some ſaid Magius did not deſerve to be ſo us'd neither; others, That ſuch a beginning would have an ill end; but they agreed at laſt to deny nothing to Hannibal, and ſo gave the old Man up to his mercy.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: See where he comes.

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.p: O what a Sight is here?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: A Rope about his Neck, and bound in Chains.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: A Carthaginian Guard upon him too.

div.stage: An Officer enters with a Guard of Carthaginians before and behind Magius, chain'd with a Rope about his Neek, and led along by a Lictor.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: Have your Eyes every way upon the Crowd;
If any man but ſeems to pity him,
Secure him as an Enemy to the State.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: You ſee, my Countrymen, the libert,
You have brought home at laſt for you, and yours.
Here, in the Forum, in the barefac'd Sun,
You ſee a Citizen of Capua,
Second to none in Name and Dignity,
Torn from his Friends, and forc'd in Chains to death;
Go meet your Hannibal, crowd all your Streets;
Dreſs up your Houſes, and your Images,
And put on all the City's Finery,
To conſecrate this Day a Feſtival
Of Barbarous Triumph over you and me.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: I'll ſpoil your ſpeech-making; drag him along.

div.stage: Exeunt, The Lictor, dragging Magius off the Stage.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: O! piteous Spectacle.

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.p: Piteous indeed,

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: This is the ſetting out of Slavery.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: 'Tis well if it goes no farther:
Not allow us to pity our Fellow Citizens!

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.p: Ay, did you mark that?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: They begin to ſhew themſelves already.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: In Colours I don't like:
We may repent too late what we have done.

sp.speaker: 4 Cit.
sp.p: O you have loſt the beſt of the Shew, the ſight of the Priſoners, and the Buſhel of Gold-Rings.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: What! there were ſo many Roman Knights kill'd, and taken at Cannae, that their ſeveral Rings, in a heap together, fill'd a Buſhel.

sp.speaker: 4 Cit.
sp.p: So they ſay, indeed.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Why, then their Buſhel lies out of all meaſure, in my opinion.

sp.speaker: 4 Cit.
sp.p: The three hundred Knights that were deliver'd to us, wou'd have been worth your ſeeing; gallant Fellows indeed, and wounded moſt of 'em.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Some body ſaid, That Junius was found among the Priſoners.

sp.speaker: 4 Cit.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Junius, our Countryman was among 'em; he was ſaid to be kill'd at Cannae, but he's alive again, and in a way to do very well.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: He's a Priſoner, you ſay.

sp.speaker: 4 Cit.
sp.p: No, his old Friend Virginius, upon the merit of his violence, and the credit of his Father Pacuvius, Has made an intereſt with Hannibal, And, they ſay, has got him his liberty.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: All in good time: but Decius Magius,
Let's follow all, to know what comes of him.

div.stage: Enter Virginius and Junius with an Officer, and Guard.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: O Junius! how art thou reſtor'd to life!
And I by miracle to happineſs!
For tho the bounteous Gods have bleſt my Fate
With all the good things, elſe of this great World;
Yet wanting thee, wanting my other ſelf,
I could not be entire to my content,
Not abſolute, nor perfect in my joy.
But they have brought thee back to me again,
And through ſuch 'mazing paths of Providence,
We cannot trace, and only can admire.
Thus thy good fortune riſes from the bad.
Hadſt thou not been at Cannae, taken there;
Had we not leagu'd our State with Hannibal;
Thou had'ſt not been among the Priſoners,
The Roman Knights, to be deliver'd here:
Thou had'ſt not ſeen thy Country, City, Friends;
Nor ſhould I had the intereſt and power
With Hannibal, to gain thy liberty.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I wonnot be oblig'd, for any thing,
I do not underſtand a benefit.
I'm Pris ner of an honourable War;
And do deſpiſe my Freedom, but on terms
As brave and honeſt, as I parted with it:
Such terms I muſt deſpair of finding here.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: We do invite you to an equal ſhare
Of all the advantages of Government,
Of Place, and Power, with us in Capua.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: Therefore I do refuſe my liberty.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: You wonnot ſure refuſe it from a Friend.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: I have no Friend, nor I pretend to none.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: You have been mine, and you have thought me yours.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: That was in our young days; when every thing
Was ſwallow'd, and went credulouſly down.
Our pleaſures hurrying on in the ſame courſe,
When we purſu'd 'em with the ſame deſires,
With the ſame ſtretch, and eagerneſs of Youth:
Our manners too in every thing ally'd;
Then we were Friends for our convenience.
But when the buſineſs of the World comes on,
Juſtling between ambitious intereſts,
Tis then, in the great voyage of our Life,
As if our Veſſels ſtruck upon a Rock,
Each ſhifts a ſeveral way to 'ſcape the wreck,
And ſink, or ſwim, my Friend; nay, plunge him down,
So by his ruin, I get ſafe to ſhore.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: It never can be ſo between us two.
I have no ambition, have no intereſt,
That Friendſhip can ſuſpect, or ſplit upon.
Friendſhip is riches, power, all, to me.
Friendſhip's another Element of life:
Water and Fire not of more general uſe,
To the ſupport and comfort of the World;
Than Friendſhip to the being of my Joy.
I would do every thing to ſerve a Friend.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: And I would ſerve a Friend in honeſt things:
I do pretend no farther. You, and I,
You ſee, have very different ſentiments;
Therefore unlikely to continue Friends.
If from our former Brotherhood of Love,
You do ſuſpect I may have any claim,
Againſt her intereſt, that ſhould have it all,
Here I renounce it, I reſign it here.
And now let's heartily ſhake hands, and part;
To your high Fortune, You; I to my Fate.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: My Fortune and your Fate ſhall be but one.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: They are impoſſible to reconcile:
You happy, I am born to be a Wretch:
You free, and I condemn'd to be a Slave.
O! had I fal'n with Honour in the Field,
How many miſeries had ended there!
Death had ſecured me then from being led
In Triumph here, over my Country's Shame.
I hate your Hannibal, I hate your Cauſe:
And now can only be a Friend to Rome.
And if I ever come at Liberty,
It ſhall be but to ſtrike againſt you all.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: You hear him, he is not to be reclaim'd.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: This is the preſent ſenſe of ſuffering;
The grief of unheal'd Wounds: all will be well.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: You cannot truſt him with his liberty.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: With my own life I will.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Have you reſolv'd
About the trifle of diſpoſing me?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: My Houſe your Priſon, I muſt be your Guard.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: With your own hands you ſet it then on fire.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: He has warn'd you, and the conſequence be yours.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: I'LE hear no more: when next thou ſpeak'ſt to me,
Let blood, and death, and ruin be the Theme.
Talk of the Maſſacres of Families,
Plunder of Cities, and whole Countries waſte.
A private miſchief is not worth the news.
Tell me that all the dire Calamities
Of raging War, chain'd up in diſcipline,
Are now broke looſe, trooping in horrid march,
To fright the World, the brood of Cerberus,
And worry all, like the black-guard of Hell.
That Luſt and Rapine do divide the Spoil:
That Giant Murder does beſtride our Streets,
Stalking in ſtate, and wading deep in Blood.
My Father Butcher'd, weltring in his Gore:
A Dagger in the Throat of my dear Child:
And thou ſhalt be as welcome then as now.
That Capua is in Univerſal Blaze;
All, all the winds of Heaven driving this way,
And nothing but my Tears to quench the Flame.
— Junius alive! ev'n that would give me Death.
In Capua too! that brings it nearer ſtill.
In the ſame houſe! that ſtabs the Dagger home:
It hurries me to Execution,
And Execution too upon the Rack:
Let me be out of pain, before he comes.
What corner ſhall I find to hide this head in?
Where is that Dungeon-darkneſs that can blind
The eye of Jealouſie? my Husband comes
To draw me to the hateful Light again,
To drag me to the tryal of my truth.
What can I plead? O guilty, guilty Wretch!
There is no courage, but in Innocence:
No conſtancy, but in an honeſt cauſe.
Thy Conſcience is a thouſand witneſſes:
And Junius, the chief Acceſſary, he
Stands out againſt thee, and confeſſes all.
I'le hear no more: pronounce my ſentence quick,
Let it be Death, to end me any way.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I need not tell you, you command all here,
And that you have your Liberty entire.
Ha! Junius! why that paleneſs on thy face?
Thy alter'd looks ſpeak thy condition,
Thou art not well.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: Indeed I am not well.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Expence of Spirits, and the loſs of Blood.
With needful care they will recruit again.
Reſt on my arm, and let me lead you in.

div.head: SCENE Changes to Favonia's Appartment.
div.stage: Favonia leaning on her hand in a Chair. Virginius leading Junius into the Room.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Favonia —

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: Ha! who calls?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: I can no more: I muſt end here,
sp.stage: Faints at the ſight of Favonia, She Shrieks at ſight of Him.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Fall into theſe Arms,
They never will refuſe to bear thee up.
Favonia, call for help; he comes again;
Stay; lend your hand; ſoft, gently, ſet him down.
sp.stage: In the Chair She riſes out of.
sp.l: How is it now?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Conofunded in my ſhame,
That my infirmity ſhould here intrude.
Your pardon, Madam, will recover me.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Rally your routed ſpirits to your aid,
Reſt will compoſe and bring 'em back again.
I cannot ſtay with you, but will return
To cheer, to comfort you, and to renew
The paſt endearments of our former Friendſhip.
I will provide you Balm for all your Wounds:
My Wife her ſelf, your kind Phyſician,
Will wait upon you, till I come again.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I'm hunted to the brink of the Abyſs:
Plunge in I muſt, and to the bottom now.
But firſt upon my Knees let me fall down,
Trembling, and aw'd, and fearful of your Frown,
Beſpeaking pardon, if I wildly ſhou d,
In queſtioning the Gods upon my Fate,
Say any thing towards diſturbing you.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: O riſe, I muſt not hear you on your Knees.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I m bleſt, that you will hear me any way.
But O! the Accent of my Voice is chang'd:
You cannot know it now in miſery.
There was a time, in the gay Spring of Life,
When every Note was as the mounting Lark's
Merry, and cheerful, to ſalute the Morn;
When all the day was made of Melody.
But it is paſt, that day is ſpent, and done,
And it has long been night, long night with me.
I have been happier, you have known me ſo.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: Alas! there is no Fortune perfect here.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Indeed I find it: When I enter'd firſt
Into the Liſt of this contending World,
I promis'd fair for a more proſperous courſe:
The Favourite of Fortune, and the Friend,
To perfect all, of my Virginius:
We liv'd the envy of our Capuan Youth,
The moſt aſpiring to the Glorious Fame
Of Friendſhip, only imitated us.
So bleſt you found us.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: Would to all the Gods,
I ne're had come between you, to divide,
To part ſuch Friends.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: O! had we parted there:
He to the rich poſſeſſion of your Charms;
I to a poorer Fortune in my Love;
Yet rich enough, and happy in content,
All had been well: But he would have me home.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: O! I remember his impatience.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: To be a Witneſs of his happineſs.
And ſo I was. I hear'd him every day
Tranſported in the Riot of the Theme;
Full of the raviſhing Diſcoveries
He hourly made in that bleſt Land of Love:
The ever riſing Springs of flowing Joy;
The hoarded Mines of treaſures, yet unborn:
With ſuch a rapture of variety
Of Pleaſures that were ever growing there.
It was not ſafe to hear, I found it ſo.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: O Curs'd effect of fooliſh Vanity!

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: What was it to approach then, to behold,
And face to face examine and compare
The Copied Beauties with the Original?
O! they were faint, and the deſcription cold,
Heavy and dead, to the inſpiring Life:
And what I thought Extravagance before,
Prov'd eaſie to the Wonders I ſaw there.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: What will this end in?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Can we reſolve to gaze upon the Sun
With ſteady Eyes? ſoon blinded by that Pride
I loſt my way; and found my ſelf too late,
Born down the torrent of a Paſſion,
That always ended in a Sea of Woe:
I plainly ſaw Ruin attend my Steps;
Therefore reſolv'd to lead 'em far away,
Where they might never come to trouble you.
But O! it was with all the violence
Of Pangs, in Death, that I at laſt reſolv'd,
And yielded to that only Remedy:
A Remedy worſe than the worſt of Deaths
To fly the Place, where I muſt die for Love,
Or live a Traitor to my Friend and Fame.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: What have you ſaid?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: If I have ſaid too much,
Believe, I rather had in ſilence dy'd,
Than to have ſpoke at all: This was the fate
I labour'd to avoid. But who can ſhun
His Deſtiny? it follows every where:
Capua, or Rome, or Cannae, ſtill the ſame.
I would have welcom'd it, that fatal day;
But there it loſt me in the Crowd of Death.
This was the place of Execution;
And it has caught, and ſeiz'd, and bound me here:
I'm on the Rack: What I diſcover now,
Is only the expreſſion of my Pain,
Wrung from my heart, long overcharg'd, and full,
Which elſe ſhould burſt with its Convulſive throws,
Rather than eaſe its Labour by a Groan,
A trembling Sigh, that might offend your Ear.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: O Junius! whither are you going? hold.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: A little farther, and I ſhall arrive
At my long home, the Goal of my Deſpair.
To ask your Pardon, wou'd repeat my Fault:
To ask your Pity, were to draw you in,
By ſteps of mercy, to a tenderneſs,
Criminal, and guilty, to reprieve a Wretch,
Who, for the Common Peace, and yours, muſt die.
There is no Ward againſt ſuch Blows as theſe;
They ſtagger me, and I at laſt muſt fall.
Since I am doom'd to be a Sacrifice
Of fatal friendſhip, and of hopeleſs love.
sp.stage: Falls at her Feet, ſhe breaks his Fall, and kneels by him to recover him.
sp.l: Here let me fall, I wou'd be offer'd here;
Allow me dying to confeſs my Love
In my laſt Sigh, and at your feet expire.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: 'Tis I am bound, and torn upon the Rack!
I cannot bear it, Junius, Junius:
Look up, and live, and I'll confeſs enough
For you, and for my ſelf, all that I know, all that I ever heard of wretchedneſs;
What you have undergone, what I have felt;
What I now feel from this tormenting Love.
Where am I going? help there— O he comes
Again to life— fly, fly to my relief.
sp.stage: Women enter, run to aſſiſt Junius, and lead him off.
sp.l: Uſe all your Arts, his weakneſs to reſtore;
My cure muſt be, never to ſee him more.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: I'VE watch't thee with a careful Parents eye,
Follow'd through all the motions of thy Soul
And cannot find it, therefore have withdrawn,
To give thee place, and opportunity.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And therefore have I follow'd you, my Lord,
To tell you what it is I labour with.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: 'Tis mighty ſure, when the great Hannibal
Not only has forgiv'n, but honour'd thee,
At his high Table, bidding thee his Gueſt,
That can diſgrace his Invitation,
Poyſon his Feaſt, and in a general Mirth,
Make ſad the brow of Youth with diſcontent.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: 'Tis a deſign to raiſe my Countries Fame.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Thy Countries Fame!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: You ſee this Dagger here,
A little inſtrument for ſo great a work,
But well employ'd, and gallantly ſtruck home.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Struck home!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Into the heart of Hannibal,
Wou'd yet attone our infamous revolt.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: O Jupiter! thou great deliverer!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I have reſolv'd to make our peace with Rome,
And ſeal it with this Carthaginian's Blood.
'Tis fit that you ſhould know what I intend:
If you approve the deed, then ſee it done;
If not, take this occaſion, and retire.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: By all the bonds of Duty, and of Love,
That tye a Son and Father's hearts in one,
I beg, implore, conjure thee to deſiſt:
Let me arreſt thee in this horrid courſe,
That leads through all the ſteps of infamy,
Into the gulf of ſure Perdition.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I think not ſo.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: But now, before the Altars of the Gods,
We interchang'd our Souls, and plighted Faith,
With right-hands joyn'd, in ſolemn, holy league
Of Sacred Truſt: and was there nothing meant
By theſe good rites of hoſpitality,
More than, when we had feaſted, drank, and laught;
To get a nearer opportunity
To perpetrate the fouleſt act of ſhame,
And Stab our Entertainer?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: How my Lord!
Our Entertainer? you compell'd me here.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Your Benefactor; he has ſav'd your life.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: So is the Robber, that but takes my goods:
And ſhall I thank him for not doing more?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: If there is nothing Sacred; if you think
Religion, Faith, and Piety, reſtraints
But for the weak, then let looſe all the Reins.
Yet when you undertake a Villany,
Act like a Man, not raſhly throw away
Honour and life in the mad enterprize.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: My life I have devoted to my Cauſe,
And Honour muſt attend it, when it goes.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: What! would you ſingly ſtrike at Hannibal?
Where is the circle of his Officers?
His waiting Slaves, and his attending Guards?
The many eyes that only wake for him?
The many hands always in arms for him?
All blind, and dead? are they confounded all?
Can you alone undaunted ſtand againſt
Thoſe looks of Terror, which arm'd Legions
Have trembled at, and Rome could not ſuſtain?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I can ſurprize him in his riots here.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: O, no, my Son, hee's not to be ſurprized.
There is an awful guard of Majeſty
About his Perſon, that denies approach:
A Majeſty of glorious Actions,
Of famous Wars, and bloody Battels gain'd,
That are his Sword and Buckler every where.
They charge around him, like Numidian Spears,
To terrify and keep off all ſurprize.
Trebie, and Thraſimene, and Cannae, all
Shelter him with the Laurels of their Fields.
The mighty Ghoſt of great Aemilius,
That waits him, as his guardian Genius now,
Would wiſh to die again, a death of ſhame,
To ſee a Boy attempt his Conqueror.
But grant you could ſurprize him, and his guards:
Yet I am there, what will you do with me?
I am his Fortreſs, I am his Defence.
Will you purſue him through a Father's Life?
If you will Stab him, Stab him then through me.
My breaſt oppos'd, firſt you muſt reach my Heart,
Before your Dagger can arrive at him.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: O, Sir, your words have ſtruck a Dagger here.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Is then the thirſt of thy revenge ſo hot,
Not to be ſlackt, but with a Father's Blood?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I'le pour out mine to quench your kindled Rage.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Let me deter thee here, rather than go
To throw away thy ſelf, and ruin me.
O let my Prayers proſper, and prevail
With thee, as for thee they prevail'd to day.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I muſt deny you nothing: but you have
Undone your Self, your Country, and your Son.
You have commanded me, and I will pay
That piety to you my Country claims.
O my dear Country! this was my laſt hope,
To have reſtored thee to thy Self and Rome.
I had prepar'd this Dagger in thy Cauſe:
But ſince my Father wreſts it from my Hand;
I can no more, but with my Grief retire,
And in the Crowd expect the common Fate.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You have withdrawn your ſelf in a bad time.
We wanted you within: the Publick has
Put on a different face from what it had:
But Smile, or Frown, we cannot mend it now.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Pray, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Why, the queſtion roſe
Upon the taking in the Tarentines.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: O, I was by, when their Ambaſſadors
Were introduced, and had their Audience.
Their buſineſs was welcom'd, and well receiv'd,
But not requiring haſte, ſoon laid aſide,
And civily diſmiſt, while I was there.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: It was ſo, and the Revellings went on.
But then, from all the quarters of the Town,
We were allarmed by clamorous complaints,
Of every kind, againſt the Soldiers.
Women, and Wine, we knew, of right were theirs,
But in a natural, and manly uſe,
Not to break through, or over-leap the bounds
Of Government, by brutal violence.
But when they came, without diſtinction,
To ſeize on all, proceeding ſo to Blood,
To Plunder, Murder, and to Raviſhment,
'Twas high time to complain.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: High time indeed.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Some call'd on you, others petition'd me:
And every Client to his Patron ran,
To ſave him, or redreſs his injuries.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: What follow'd then?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Maherbal ſtanding by,
The Carthaginian General of the Horſe,
With his blunt honeſty, told Hannibal,
That from the Soldiers Luxury, he foreſaw
Capua would prove to him and his affairs,
Fatal, as ever Cannae did to Rome.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Ha! that was home.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Hannibal rouz'd at that,
And gave his orders for a ſpeedy March:
But not ſo much, on what Maherbal ſaid,
It is believ'd, as on ſome News from Rome.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: We never wiſh'd him to continue here.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: But what ſhould be the News that has ſo ſoon
Alter'd his Meaſures?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: O, no matter what
Can come from Rome; he has ſerv'd the preſent turn,
And we can ſerve our ſelves againſt the next:
We muſt be near him, while he ſtays with us.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: IT was her hand that rais'd me from the Grave;
It was her Mercy that repriev'd my Fate:
She meant it in a kind Compaſſion,
Tho it had been the tendreſt Charity,
To let the rigor of the Sentence paſs
Upon my Life, and put me out of pain.
I am redeem'd from the arreſt of Death,
To pine, and languiſh in a wretched Life.
Is there no Remedy; Want will be heard,
And anſwer'd too; I could turn Begger here:
When once it comes to the extremity
To take, or ſtarve, there is no more a right
Of Property; all things lie common then
In Nature's Field; from Heav'n to Hell is ours,
For our ſupport, to compaſs any way.
What hinders then but I may be reliev'd?
I have diſcharg'd my ſelf from all the Bonds
Of friendſhip, duty, that encumber'd me;
And I am left at large, and free to take
All opportunities that can aſſiſt
To make me—What? a Villain. Am I free?
Diſcharg'd of all my obligations?
Why am I here, plac'd as another Lord
Over this Family, and not a friend?
Is then the Truſt and Confidence repos'd
In me, and my fidelity, no Bond?
Theſe are State Morals; but adverſity
Has ever been an evil Counſellor;
And always will be ſo: I'll hear no more.
I have nothing left me but my honeſty,
To write my Epitaph, and grace my Tomb:
Thither I'm going, O Favonia! ſtay,
I ſee you ſhun me, let me only take
A parting look, I wonnot dare to ſpeak,
If I ſhou'd ſigh, it is my laſt adieu.

div.head: SCENE the Forum.
div.stage: Enter three or four Citizens of the better ſort.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: ARE theſe our Friends? what cou'd they have done worſe by us, if they had been our Enemies?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: If our City had been taken by Storm, they could but have raviſh'd our Wives and Daughters.

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.p: And put us to the Sword; you forget that Man.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: No, we were reſerv'd for a worſe Puniſhment, to ſtand by, and look on, as ſcandalous Witneſſes of our infamy and diſgrace.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: There's nothing free from their inſolence and outrage.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Every place prophan'd by their Rioting and Drunkenneſs.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: They have invaded every thing that's dear to us.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: No Property in any thing.

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.p: Eſpecially the Petticoat; nay, it has been very bad indeed; but 'twill mend now, they are marcht away to the Tarentines; and Tarentum take 'em, I ſay.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Hannibal is march'd indeed with his Army, but has left a Gariſon behind him; What does he mean by that?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: To protect us againſt the Romans.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: The Romans! why, we have been told all along there was no danger of them.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: I wiſh we may find it ſo.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: There's no believing any thing now a-days; not a Syllable of truth in the Mouth of Report, for an honeſt Man to walk by.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: 'Tis all Party, and ſerving a turn.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: There was no News currant a great while, but the Diſtreſs of the Romans, the Miſery they were brought to, and the utter impoſſibility of ever appearing in arms agen; that was all the reaſon we had for deſerting our old friends.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Now that turn's ſerv'd, and not ſo much care taken to ſtifle Intelligence; we hear of nothing but their Induſtry and Virtue; the Preparations and Power of the Romans: I am credibly informed they have a Conſular Army in the Field, and in a condition to try their fortune again with Hannibal, if he pleaſes.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: He may thank himſelf, if they ſhould beat him now.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: If he had march'd directly to Rome from Cannae, as he was advis'd.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: But he ſtay'd there playing the Merchant, and ſelling his Priſoners.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Which provoked Maherbal to tell him, That he knew how to conquer, better than to uſe his Victory.

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.p: If the Romans are ſo ſtrong, what may become of us then?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Nay, we have pull'd our old Houſes upon our Heads, and may be buried in the Ruins, for ought we know.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: We have deſerv'd as ill as we can of 'em.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: And have nothing to pray the Gods, but that they may never have it in their Power to reward us to our Deſerts.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: That's all we have to truſt to.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Is't poſſible! he cannot be ſo baſe, forgetful, ſo ungrateful to his Friends.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Contain your ſelf, at leaſt here in the Street; let us not be the firſt in our complaints, who were the forwardeſt—

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: And we are paid moſt richly for our pains.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: I will come home
To you, and there we will enlarge our hearts—

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: In ſpight of all his Guards, and ſpeak bold Truths:
I ſhall expect you with impatience.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Bold Truths! they may return upon our ſelves:
For if I ſpeak Truth boldly, as it is,
I cannot be ſurpriz'd, that Hannibal
Should leave a Gariſon, ſhould not truſt me
With full command, which I had juſt before
Abus'd, betray'd, and given up to him:
To him, I mean to my Ambition:
This little ſtand of Fortune gives me time
To look about, and ſee what I have done.
The many violent ſteps that I have made
To bring me here, to my untimely fall,
It may be too, when Thraſimene was fought,
Being chief Magiſtrate of Capua,
Had Hannibal marcht this way, I had deſign'd
The Senate's ſlaughter, to deliver up
The City ſo. I was prevented then:
But now have done it — not ſo bloodily.
What was the Romans murder in our Baths,
Was not that Bloody, and ſet on by me?
I had forgot: 'tis dangerous to awake
A guilty Memory. Decius Magius too
Stands out to accuſe me — but he's ſtill alive.
O I remember all his Curſes now:
May they be blown about, and loſt in Air;
Not ſhed their Venom upon me and mine.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: ALL cloſe, and ſilent! as in depth of Night
Wrapt up in darkneſs! in the inner room
I ſpy a winking Lamp, that weakly ſtrikes
The ambient Air, ſcarce kindling into Light:
That, ſeeble as it is, ſhall be my guide.
There I ſhall find her in her pomp of Grief.
Dare I invade her ſacred ſolitude?
My Heart ſinks in me, and my trembling knees
Knock, and forſake me, when I wou'd go on;
Warning me not to touch forbidden ground.
Forbidden! ſo are all good things to me.
Nothing to hope, I nothing have to fear.

div.head: SCENE changes, and ſhows Favonia aſleep on a Couch in an undreſs.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: She conſecrates the Place, where e're She is,
With reverence: We enter Temples ſo.
Where are the Terrors, that ſhou'd keep me back?
Her frowns, the greateſt, are diſarm'd in ſleep.
O may the ſofteſt down of ſweet repoſe
Receive thee gently on the Bed of Peace,
And fold thee cloſe in the kind arms of reſt:
That undiſturb'd, this Opportunity
May now be mine, to feed my famiſht Eyes.
The ſickning light is envious, and grows pale,
With looking on her: 'tis a ſight indeed
For the high mounted Sun, in all his Pride,
To ſtop, and wonder at— let me fix here—
Stretch wide the Gates of ſight to take her in,
In the full triumph of her conquering charms.
My eager Eyes devour her Beauties up,
Inſatiable, and hungring ſtill for more.
