O! the rich Glutton, that enjoys this ſtore!
Nothing to ſpare from ſuperfluity,
To feed my wants, my Feaver burns me up,
O! let me quench it at this healing Spring.
The Spring is ſacred; a Divinity
Protects the place; thrice happy, happy, he
Who may plunge in, and bathe, and wanton there.
But I may taſte the coolneſs of the ſtream.
And I will drink the Cordial of a kiſs,
From this dear hand, reach'd out to comfort me.
She wakes!
sp.stage: Virginius and Pacuvius at the Door entring.
sp.l: What noiſe! I may retire unſeen.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: A Man here with my Wife! O give me way

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: Who's there? my Lord?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Where is the Villain? where?

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: O! where indeed? my Father! on my knees
Let me proteſt, and ſwear my Innocence.
I am betray'd, and loſt.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Thou art indeed.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: This was contriv'd, and lay'd for his eſcape:
And this Apartment fitted, and prepar'd
To be the Scene of their adulterous Luſt.
Where is there ſuch another Wretch on earth?
Ruin'd, undone in every intereſt,
Betray'd, and ruin'd in my deareſt truſt!
But I will be the Executioner
Of my juſt rage, and here begin revenge—

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Strike home, it is the Sword of Juſtice now.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Have you condemn'd her?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: I applaud the deed.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I wonnot kill thee in thy Fathers ſight.
That were to act a murder upon him.
Here, take her, Sir, I give her up to you.
Your Houſes honour is engag'd with mine.
Do with her what is fit for you, and me.
You are her Judge, condemn, or ſet her free.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: LET Capua ſink under the Rods of Rome:
Her Axes hew your Branches to the ſtock,
The Liteleſs trunk, never to ſprout agen.
The Gods appointment always is the beſt,
But every way your ruine will be juſt.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.p: If all our Nobles are of your mind, what muſt become of the City in a little time?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: It muſt become the injur'd Roman's ſpoil,
At the beſt, that, and you their faithleſs Slaves,
As you deſerve, unworthy to be Friends.
Now, now the day of your account draws on.
The Roman Conſuls come as Miniſters
Of Wrath, and Terror to this guilty Town,
Arm'd with the kindled Juſtice of the Gods
Againſt your Crimes, with their avenging Bolts
From Heav'n, and the devouring Flames of Hell,
To burn, deſtroy, and ruine you, and yours.
They have inveſted you with Fire, and Sword.
Famine, and Peſtilence will follow ſoon
In the ſtarv'd rear, to ſeize, and faſten on
Thoſe Wretches, who juſt ſcape the ſtroke of War.
You have variety of Miſery
Before you, in this ſiege, to pick, and chuſe
What Death you pleaſe, but think not to eſcape.
Your Hannibal has left you, with the Gods,
And all good Men, to ſure perdition.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.p: A ſorry comforter—

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.p: Of tother ſide; no friend of ours; no matter what he ſays. He wiſhes it were worſe, if poſſible.

sp.speaker: 3. Cit.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis ev'n bad enough; and how 'twill be better I don't know.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.p: We're in a miſerable condition, that's the truth on't, and which way to apply our ſelves for a remedy—

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.p: Ay, that's the way, if we cou'd hit on't.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: Let's to the Forum,
There we ſhall find our fellow Citizens,

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.p: We'll joyn with them, for ſomething muſt be done.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: What is't to me, my Country, Capua?
Who does maintain, or who deſerts her Cauſe?
Favonia is the Province of my Care.
And her I have deſerted, baſely left,
How! baſely! nay, abandon'd to the Rage,
It may be, of a jealous Husband too.
Ha! whether am I hurry'd by my Fears?
Had I foreſeen but half the Accidents,
That threaten now, what wou'd I not have done?
I wou'd have ſnach'd her from his cruel Hands.
And may do ſtill. I will declare my Love,
Clear her ſuſpected Honour to the World,
Or juſtifie my Paſſion by Revenge.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Let him diſpoſe of her, as he thinks beſt:
It was a Task unnaturally impos'd,
And therefore willingly I lay it down.
Beſides there is a publick Conflict here,
Within this Breaſt, admits not private Cares.
Say, have you ſent to Vibius Virius,
And Marius Bloſius?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: As you order'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: And what?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: They will come home to you.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: 'Tis well.
Let no body diſturb me, till they come.
They ſent no News?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: There's none worth ſending, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Worth ſending! true, 'twill come it ſelf too ſoon.
But we may boldly hear what we muſt feel.
'Tis natural to enquire how the World goes—

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Towards an end with us, 'tis to be fear'd,
And Capua, the Expedition is
Incredible, that carries on the Seige.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: We often ask, in Caſes of Deſpair,
When we are ſure the Anſwer cannot pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Hannibal try'd to raiſe it, but in vain:
And now 'tis ſaid that he is march'd to Rome:
That way to draw the Conſuls from our Walls,
To ſave their City, and defend themſelves.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Leave me, and bring in what Reports you hear.
We cannot anſwer for unborn Events:
The Gods have plac'd 'em in the Hands of Fate,
To Shape, and Faſhion for their high Decrees;
At their appointed time, to bring 'em forth,
To baffle human Wit, and Induſtry.
Elſe in the Courſe of Probability;
And as Appearances preſented things,
Rome was to fall, and Capua was to riſe.
But Fate, it ſeems, has otherwiſe ordain'd.
There is a ſecret Power within the Scene
That works unſeen, and makes ſo quick a ch
I cannot ſtand the Taunts of bad Succeſs,
And therefore wonnot meet 'em in the crow
I have hitherto been on the winning ſide.
We have another Game of Fortune now,
And I will looſe as little as I can.
I cannot make the Figure that I wou'd,
But need not make a bad one; that's in me;
If it grows worſe, I know my Remedy.

sp.speaker: 3. Cit.
sp.p: No Tidings to comfort us?

sp.speaker: 4. Cit.
sp.p: Sad Times, ſad Times, and running on to be worſe, as faſt as they can drive.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.p: Did ever People fall from ſuch a Pinacle of Proſperity, unto ſuch a Gulph of Deſtruction, in ſo little a time?

sp.speaker: 3. Cit.
sp.p: Never, never.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.p: Our Sallys did ſomething at firſt to hinder their Works, but to no purpoſe now, they'r beaten back upon every Attempt, and dare not look the Romans in the Face.

sp.speaker: 3. Cit.
sp.p: There's no peeping upon the Walls.

sp.speaker: 4. Cit.
sp.p: The Engines play ſo thick, they'r about your Ears before you'r aware of 'em.

sp.speaker: 3. Cit.
sp.p: Not a Spade employ'd in the Trenches, but digs a Capuan Grave.

sp.speaker: 4. Cit.
sp.p: Wee'r in a ſad Condition indeed.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.p: There's no Body to Command, but Boſtar, and Hanno, the Carthaginians, and how the Capuans obey them, you may believe.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.p: The Garriſon fights hard for us, to ſave themſelves; but they'll pay their Quarters before they leave us.

sp.speaker: 3. Cit.
sp.p: They have brought us into the Crime, and wont forſake us in the Puniſhment.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.p: Nay, they have done all they can for us with Hannibal.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.p: And for themſelves, for they muſt pay our Scores; but what was that all?

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.p: Why, they ſent to him, to complain that he had abandon'd the Town, and, as it were, yielded it up himſelf to the Fury of the Romans; and withall beſeeching him, that he wou'd come to their Relief, who were not only Beſieg'd, but ſhut up in the Works, and almoſt in the Hands of the Enemy,

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.p: Upon which he came to look upon his Patients at a diſtance, ſhook his Head in deſpair of our State, and went to Rome for better Advice.

sp.speaker: 3. Cit.
sp.p: He ſent us his Reaſon for ſo doing.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.p: But the Conſuls are here ſtill, for all his Reaſon, and the Praetor too; their Armies are not drawn off, as ſoon as Hannibal march'd out of Capua, the Romans came upon us, you know, as if they had hit the opportunity, they had been aiming at ſolong; they did not come here to be drawn away by every Motion of the Enemy.

sp.speaker: 4. Cit.
sp.p: No, no, they wont leave us ſo.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.p: Therefore my Advice is, either to try what our Deſpair can do, in making a bold puſh, or take the Benefit of the Conſuls Proclamation.

sp.speaker: 3. Cit.
sp.p: What's that? What does the Proclamation ſay?

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.p: It offers Life, and liberty to all thoſe that ſurrender themſelves in four and twenty Hours.

sp.speaker: 3. Cit.
sp.p: Why, ay, why don't we lay hold on the Proclamation?

sp.speaker: 4. Cit.
sp.p: At leaſt let's ſtay for an Anſwer from Hannibal. Some Mauritanians have undertaken, in the Name of Deſerters, to get to him thro' the Roman Camp.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.p: And will be wiſe enough never to come back agen. In the mean time, we ſtand like Condemn'd Men, with the Halter about our Necks, but no body attempts any thing for himſelf, or the Publick.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.p: What wou'd you have us do? The chief Citizens have ſhut themſelves up in their Houſes, expecting their Ruine, with the Deſtruction of their Country.

sp.speaker: 3. Cit.
sp.p: The Nobles have deſerted us, and the Care of the Common-wealth.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.p: Why then, in the firſt place, let us go, and ſet Decius Magius at Liberty.
Agreed, agreed; 'twas luckily thought upon.

sp.speaker: 3. Cit.
sp.p: He's a good Man, and a lover of his Country.

sp.speaker: 4. Cit.
sp.p: And a Lover of the People.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.p: Nay, he never quarrell'd with us, but for our Faults, when we deſerv'd it.

sp.speaker: 3. Cit.
sp.p: If we had been govern'd by him, Friends—

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.p: Let us clap him up at the Head of the Government.

sp.speaker: 3. Cit.
sp.p: And his Enemies in his place.

sp.speaker: 4. Cit.
sp.p: We can't do better.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.p: And then we'll go about the City to Summon the Senate, and tell the Senators plainly what they muſt truſt to; that unleſs they aſſemble immediately to look after the Publick, we'll ſet their Houſes on Fire about their Ears, and begin with them in the Ruin of Capua.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.p: We'll Sacrifice them to their Country, rather then give up our Wives and Children to the Enemy.

sp.speaker: 3. Cit.
sp.p: And ſo we'll tell 'em plainly.

sp.speaker: 4. Cit.
sp.p: There's nothing elſe to be done.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.p: If we are to be Ruin'd, let it begin at our Betters?

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: 'Tis time enough for us, when it comes to our turn.
And I'll take my turn, tho' it be at the Gallows.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.p: Why, that's well ſaid, there's ſomething to be expected from our honeſt endeavours. Therefore all hands to Decius Magius.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: You know the reſt, tell her that I am here.

div.head: SCENE opens and ſhews Favonia on the Ground.
div.l: Where are you? on the ground! it does become
The preſent Poſture of your fall'n Eſtate,
Fallen from the higheſt pitch of Happineſs,
Into the loweſt depth of Miſery.
Yet I will raiſe you; wou'd I cou'd reſtore you
To the admir'd height, in which you ſtood,
Of Fame, and Virtue; but it cannot be.
As well I may refix a new fall'n Star,
In his bright Orb, to light the World agen.
I come to viſit you.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: I durſt not truſt you in a Father's Hand.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: I have no Friend.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: O! that the time ſhou'd come,
That you ſhou'd ever ſay you have no Friend,
When I am near you. Yes, you have a Friend,
A Friend you ſhou'd not have, no more of that.
I am to tell you what a Friend you've loſt:
And then compute your Gains.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: I have loſt all
That ever was of Value to my Peace.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You have deſtroy'd all that was in your Pow'r:
And you well know your Pow'r to ruine me.
You've thrown away a Husband, and his Love,
That follow'd you, as Nature does her Works;
To nurſe, and raiſe you to Perfection.
Had all the good things of this Earth been mine,
And mine the Pow'r to draw their Spirits off,
Into a Quinteſſence of Happineſs,
I had beſtow'd the precious Draught on you.
And in return.—

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: O I could make you none,
To your Deſerts.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: In barbarous Return,
You have reach'd out the Gall of Bitterneſs
To daſh my Cup, and poyſon all my Joys.
I cou'd have ſweetned it with my Revenge,
Which I reſtrain'd. I held your Father's Hand,
Stretch'd out to take away your guilty Life.
For when I heard he had pronounc'd your Death,
And Sign'd the Execution, tho' I knew
You had deſerv'd it of my Wrongs, and Me,
I cou'd not hold, but flew to your Relief.
And why? Is it becauſe my Nature is
Inſenſible, and cannot feel a Wrong?
Stupid, and deadned to the Senſe of Shame?
Or that I'm noted for my Eaſineſs
In finding out Excuſes to forgive?
And pardon faſter than they injure me?
Is that the Reaſon that I reſcu'd you?
You know me better, no, Favonia, no,
'Twas Pity came into the Place of Rage.
But do not therefore think that I am ſit,
For my Diſgrace, becauſe I pitty'd you.
Juſtice her ſelf-Condemns with a Remorſe,
And pitty's while ſhe ſtrikes, beſides I thought,
That you, and you, who for ſo many Years
Had liv'd, as Friends, ſhou'd have a time to part.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: O Miſery! that I muſt nothing ſay
In my Defence, to clear my Innocence,

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Hold, have a care, no more of Innocence,
Or a Defence, if you inſiſt on that,
I ſhall break thro' the Temper I propos'd,
And then I cannot ſay where I ſhall end.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: Well, I have done.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Not but you have an Advocate ſtill here,
Within this Breaſt, and not to be remov'd,
That in Defiance of a Cauſe ſo foul,
So deſperate, and ſo loſt, will yet be heard.
But then it does pretend but to adviſe,
And warn me to be cautious what I do,
Well to conſider what I undertake,
Pondring to weigh the heavy Conſequence,
And not revenge my ſelf upon my ſelf.
As that's the caſe, unleſs I am reſolv'd.
Never to want what I wou'd throw away.
And who can know his Reſolution?
Who can be ſure, that he is well enough
Acquainted with the Temper of his Heart.
To anſwer for its Proof and Conſtancy?
To know it's ſtrength ſufficient to ſupport
So great a Loſs, to bear a Loſs, like yours?
The Loſs of all, that ever I held dear.
A Loſs, to beggar me, and all my Hopes.
Theſe were the Thoughts that flew to your Relief,
And have preſerv'd you for this Interview.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: More terrible than Death it ſelf to me.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You cannot think I come to pardon you.
No, all that I endeavour, or can gain
Upon my Wrongs, is to diſarm my Rage.
And let it paſs among the ſtrange Effects
Of that commanding Pow'r, you always had
Upon my Heart, that you are yet alive.
But I am ſtill contriving my Revenge;
Still meditating how to puniſh you;
And I am in a way that pleaſes me:
It ſatisfies my Juſtice better too,
Than the Atonement of your ſpotted Blood.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: There is no Remedy, no way to ſave
My Innocence, but by accuſing him,
Who always has been dearer than my Life.
It muſt be he, that cou'd purſue me there.
If he has ſcap'd with ſafety, I am pay'd,
Tho' 'tis a heavy loſs of Life, and Fame.

div.stage: Virginius returns with a Child in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Here is a little Innocent, that comes
To Mourn with you: Soon as ſhe can ſpeak plain,
She'll tell you, 'tis an undone Mothers Loſs
Has brought her hither, to be Nurs'd in Tears.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: O! may ſhe never know her Mothers Fate.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Nor the Diſhonour of her Father, but
Inheriting her Parents Infamy,
She muſt grow up with the Diſgrace, and Shame.
Look on her well.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: My Eyes, and Heart are full of her.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Look on her as it were to be the laſt,
The laſt, laſt look that you may ever have.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: This Object I wou'd wiſh to cloſe my Eyes.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You muſt remember how ſhe has been bred,
The fondled Darling of our rival Loves.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: Who are to ſtrive in fondneſs of her now?
Who to ſupply a tender Mothers Care?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: O! that the Reaſon of my Love ſhou'd prove,
Shou'd ever prove the reaſon of my Hate!
How have I hung upon the little Lines
Of that dear Face, with a fond Father's Joy,
To find the Mother there in Minature,
By Natures Hand Copy'd in every Look!
I pray'd the God's ſhe might reſemble you,
And now abhor the Likeneſs I deſr'd—
I cannot look upon her, but ſhe brings
Her Mothers Crimes into my Memory—
When you are in your Grave, the ſight of her
Will raiſe you from the Dead, to haunt my Peace,
To plague, and puniſh me, take her away.
I wonnot throw her out to Beggary,
But for your ſake will neve ſee her more.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: O miſerable Woman! muſt I be
The Ruine of my Child!
sp.stage: She ſnatches up the Child, the Women come about her to take the Child.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Away with her.
Why am I not obey'd? Force her away.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: O let her ſtay but for a parting hour—

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: No, not a Minute, not a Moments ſtay.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.p: To take a farewel Kiſs.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You've ſeen your laſt of her.
Now ſhe has wound her ſelf about your Heart,
Now ſhe has hold of all the Strings of Life,
Now tear her thence— that you at laſt may feel
sp.stage: Forcing the Child from her ſhe falls on the Floor.
sp.l: Some of the Tortures you prepar'd for me.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: The God's muſt give me Patience to ſupport
What they inflict, this is a thouſand Deaths.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: When I can entertain you at this rate,
I'll viſit you agen, in the mean time
You know your Lodging, I muſt ſee you in.
You'll have ſufficient leiſure to reflect
Upon the Follies that have brought you here.
You've made your ſelf unworthy of the World,
And therefore never ſhall appear agen,
But live forlorn, immur'd within theſe Walls.
Who's there?
sp.stage: A Servant enters with a Dagger in one Hand, and a Bowl in t'other, and gives 'em to Virginius, who places 'em on a Table by Favonia.
sp.l: I have your Father's Preſent yet to bring.
He ſends a Dagger, and a poyſon'd Draught,
In your Extremity to comfort you.
When you are weary of this Slavery:
You have that wretched choice to ſet you free.

div.stage: The Scene ſhuts upon Favonia, he goes off.

div.head: SCENE I. The Forum.
div.stage: Pacuvius, Vibius Virius Marius Bloſius, with the Senators in their ſeveral Parties.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.l: WE are met here, and only to be made
More certain of inevitable Fate:
Each Moment brings us Matter of Deſpair,
And no one to propoſe a Remedy.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: The Mauritanians, who were hir'd, and ſent,
And, as Deſerters, undertook to paſs
The Roman Camp, and get to Hannibal,
Diſcover'd by the Conſuls to be Spies,
Fifty in number were condemn'd to be
Firſt ſtrip'd, and Scourg'd, then with their Hands cut off,
In that moſt lamentable plight driv'n back
To Capua, to let us ſee the News.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: To let us ſee what we are to expect.

sp.speaker: 3 Sen.
sp.l: To let us read in bloody Characters
The Vengeance that is laid in ſtore for us.

sp.speaker: 4 Sen.
sp.l: The Spectacle has ſunk the People ſo,
They dare no longer think of a Defence,
And talk of nothing but Surrendring now.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: This Accident has cut our Commerce off,
All our Intelligence with Hannibal.
We've nothing farther to expect from him.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: And the God's know, but little from our ſelves.
Within. Bear back, make way for our Deliverer.
Do you not know good Decius Magius.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.l: O! Decius Magius! you'r a wellcome Man
Among us, you were never wanted more.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: 'Tis a bad Day for Capua, when a Weak,
Old, uſeleſs Man comes to be wanted ſo.
But any thing is welcome in Diſtreſs.
I'm ſorry for the Cauſe that brings me here,
Tho' it has brought me back to Liberty,
From Dungeon Darkneſs to the Heavenly Light.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: We never were in ſuch a wretched need.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I hear how Matters go with us, all wrong,
And fear me, 'tis too late to ſet 'em right.
My Pow'r is very poor, but yet you may
Employ it, as you pleaſe, for Capua,
For I am ſtill devoted to her Cauſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.p: We cannot hope to have the Town reliev'd.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: Nor are we able to defend it long.

sp.speaker: 3 Sen.
sp.l: The Roman Clemency has oft been try'd
On deſperate Occaſions, and been found,
When all has fail'd, the only Remedy.

sp.speaker: 4. Sen.
sp.l: And let us not deſpair of its effects,
Its good effects on us.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: 1. Sen.
sp.p: To pacifie the fury of our Fate.

sp.speaker: 2. Sen.
sp.p: Not to enrage it by oppoſing it.

sp.speaker: 3. Sen.
sp.p: But freely give what they have pow'r to take.

sp.speaker: 1. Sen.
sp.l: We have agreed, the greateſt part of Us,
To ſend our Legates to the Conſuls Camp,
And offer up the Town, to ſave our lives.

sp.speaker: 4. Sen.
sp.l: And you are come, good Decius Magius,
The fitteſt Suppliant in your Country's Cauſe.

sp.speaker: 1. Sen.
sp.l: You have deſerv'd, and you may well pretend
An Intereſt with the Roman Generals.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: An Intereſt againſt their Intereſt!
There's very little to expect from that.

sp.speaker: 1. Sen.
sp.p: We will ſurrender at diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: And that is but a wretched Embaſſie.
But if you think it is the only way
To do you Service, and you are agreed.

sp.speaker: 2. Sen.
sp.p: We are agreed there is no other way.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: What ſays Pacuvius? You are yet to ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: I wou'd ill become my character, to joyn
In this adviſe of ſupplicating Rome,
In our diſtreſs, who, may be, was the firſt
To urge her Ruine, by deſerting her.
But if I were no more obnoxious,
No more accountable for our revolt,
Than he that acted leaſt, yet I muſt think,
From what we've done to them, and they to us,
There is no hope of pardon at their hands.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: A Pardon! 'tis a Play-thing for a Child,
To ſtill the preſent fit of frowardneſs;
A Man can never ſet his heart upon't.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Now, when a Foreign Enemy inſults,
And Hannibal himſelf that Enemy,
When all things are permitted to the Sword,
Brandiſh'd, and flaming over Italy,
At ſuch a time, forgetting Hannibal,
And every threatned danger, to ſend here
Both Conſuls, with their Armies Conſular,
Looks as they did intend to make their Wars
Only on us, not Carthage more abhorr'd
Than Capua, as if they did not come
For Fame, or Victory, but for revenge.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: It may be ſo, and that they come to raiſe
A Monument, to warn ſucceeding times,
Never to injure, in whatever State
Their Fortune is, the Citizens of Rome.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: The very Savages, and fierceſt Beaſts,
Do but approach their Dens, and they will leave
Their deſtin'd Prey, to ſave their helpleſs Young.
The Romans are more eager yet than they.
For not the leaguer of their City Rome,
Their Wives, their Children (whoſe imploring cries,
And lamentations almoſt reach 'em here)
Their Altars, Hearths, the Temples of the Gods,
The Sepulchers of their great Anceſtors.
In danger to be violated all
By Hannibal, can once remove 'em hence,
From the determin'd ſpoil of Capua.
So greedy are they of our Puniſhment,
Of ſuch a burning thirſt to drink our Blood.
Therefore, for my part, I will ſeek no aid
Out of my ſelf: while I am Maſter of
My liberty, I can take care for one.

sp.speaker: 1. Sen.
sp.l: You, who have made your ſelves unworthy of
Pardon, and mercy, juſtly may deſpair.
But we have hopes in Decius Magius.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Alas!

sp.speaker: 2. Sen.
sp.l: Take the three hundred Roman Knights
Along with you, that are our Priſoners.

sp.speaker: 3. Sen.
sp.p: That was a lucky thought, make all the Friends—

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Adverſity will find but very few.

sp.speaker: 3. Sen.
sp.p: What force you can.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: And all, I fear, too weak,

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: You then, who ſeem to have another ſenſe
Of what we owe to the Immortal Gods,
And our immortal ſelves, in theſe extremes,
I do invite you to take part with me,
In the kind entertainment of this Night,
Which I've prepar'd for many more good Friends.
The Wine, and Company I know are good:
The Supper choſen well, and elegant:
For who can tell but it may be our laſt.
If it ſo prove; indulge the Genius,
Enlarge the Soul, and feaſt the ſenſes high:
We'll ſacrifice at laſt to Liberty.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: O Junius! 'tis unworthy of the Man,
Who calls you Friend, ſo ſcandalous a Fate.
But do not think that I am reconcil'd,
Humbled, and tam'd to my diſhonour, no.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: I know you can't be wanting to your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I wanted to acquit my ſelf to you,
And therefore I have found you luckily,
To go with me —

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: You may command your Friend.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: To be a witneſs that I treat the Wretch
As She deſerves from me, and my revenge.

div.stage: Favonia enters with a Dagger in one hand, and a Bowl in tother.

sp.speaker: Fav.
sp.l: A Fathers Preſent to a luckleſs Child!
His ſending it, and by a Husbands hands,
Shou'd have determin'd me, before this time,
In what I have to do, 'tis but to dye.
And that I've meditated, ſtudy'd long;
And often wiſht; but yet this Dagger here,
This Ruffian Dagger, like a Murderer,
That does delight in Blood, looks terrible.
There's nothing horrid in this friendly Bowl:
And it will do the deed as certainly,
And ſatisfie my angry Fate as well.
sp.stage: She drinks, throws the Bowl one way and the Dagger another.
sp.l: 'Tis paſt; the little argument of Life
Is at an end; and Death will ſoon conclude.
This is the fatal period of our Crimes,
Ending at laſt in certain Puniſhment.
And yet my Crimes, methinks, might well have paſt
For my misfortunes, to be pity'd,
Rather than puniſh'd; but I muſt not tax
The juſtice of the Gods; they have their ends
In every thing they do; they have thought fit
To judge 'em Crimes, and ſo to doom 'em here.
Perhaps to warn too negligent a World,
By my example, how they do engage
In little things, that may be dangerous.
If there is any profit of my Death,
'Tis well, I do not grudge the benefit;
For I begin to find its comfort here.
sp.stage: Laying her ſelf down on the Floor.

div.stage: Enter Virginius, and Junius to Favonia; Junius runs to her aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Extended on the Floor; is this a ſight
To triumph in?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: The Dagger, or the Bowl,
Has reſcu'd her, and diſappointed me.
I fear ſhe's almoſt got out of my reach.
sp.stage: Virginius kneels at her feet, Junius at her head.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: She's in the Pangs of Death.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: There let her ſtay,
And linger Ages out in Agony,
To glut my Eyes, and ſatiate my revenge.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: She's going! O! Favonia! ſhe is gone!
sp.stage: Favonia dyes, Junius weeping over her.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Why let her go, and with her all my Plagues.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I came to be a witneſs of thy Truth,
And Innocence; but ſhou'd have come before
To ſave thy Life—

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Methinks you are too much
Concern'd for her.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Begone, and leave me here.
Your Title carry'd to the end of life;
No farther; you have put an end to that:
And now I honeſtly may ſet up mine.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: What Title?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: To revenge her Death on you.
sp.stage: Junius ſtarts upon his knees, ſeizes upon Virginius, they riſe in a ſtruggle, Junius draws his Sword upon him.
sp.l: You have involv'd me in this Murder here:
And made me an Accomplice of a deed,
To damn us both down to the loweſt Hell.
If you dare juſtifie it, draw your Sword.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Dare juſtifie it?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: Dare.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You know I dare.
Another Man had prov'd my daring too,
Before this time.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: So every Coward ſays,

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Nay, then 'tis paſt; this only anſwers that.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: 'Tis as it ſhou'd be: I was not to live.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: I cannot long.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Then I have been a Friend
Indeed, if I have haſten'd on your Death.
For when I have confeſs'd a few ſad Truths,
You'll find I only have prevented you
From laying violent hands upon your grief,
Curſing the light, and falling to deſpair.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Your words have ſtuck attention in my heart.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Favonia is moſt innocent, and wronged:
And you, and I the only guilty here.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: But prove her ſo, and I ſhall dye with joy.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: In lov'd her, for I may avow it now,
And you may thank your ſelf, who were the cauſe,
By bringing me into your Family.
I lov'd her with a paſſion, that no bounds
Cou'd circumſcribe, no violence cou'd tame,
No Council moderate, no Friendſhip cure.
Therefore I went to Rome, reſolv'd to breath
My ſighs in Foreign Air, not to diſturb
Your Intereſt, or Favonia's Innocence.
I languiſht many Years; my Fate thought fit
To bring me back; and you wou'd have me home.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: In left her with you.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I that conflict, I
Confeſs'd what I had ſuffer'd for my love:
She pity'd me, and I deſir'd no more.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Say on, while I have leiſure to attend.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: The Man you found in her Apartment, was
Your wretched Friend: I thought to 'ſcape unſeen.
But that poor caution has undone us all.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: What was your Buſineſs there?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I went to take
A parting look, reſolv'd to end my griefs,
And trouble her no more. Favonia was
Ev'n Innocent of my being there.
I found her ſleeping with her harmleſs Thoughts:
And She but wak'd, as you approach'd the Room,
In a ſurprize, to find her ſelf undone.
This Writing I have drawn to vouch for me,
In all the circumſtances of this tale:
And the Gods try me by the Truth it bears.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: A ſolemn adjuration! and no doubt
Moſt heavenly true; and all this is the work
Of my own folly; had I been content
With that fa •… portion of felicity,
The Gods beſlow'd upon me in a Wife;
How happy had I been! but I muſt bring
My Friend home to uſurp upon her right.
And what's the conſequence! Ruine, and Death.
The approach of Death makes me leſs ſenſible.
I've loſt my Wife, and Friend, and now my ſelf.

div.head: SCENE Pacuvius Houſe.
div.stage: Pacuvius, Vibius Virius, Marius Bloſius, with Seven or Eight Senators riſing from a Feaſt.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Who, who wou'd baſely lag behind in life,
Only to ſee how many wretched ways
Our Enemies will find out to puniſh us?

sp.speaker: 5 Sen.
sp.l: Theſe Eyes ſhall never be Spectators of
My Countries Ruine.

sp.speaker: Vib.
sp.l: Nor will I behold
The ravage, and the havock of our Spoils —

sp.speaker: 6 Sen.
sp.p: Nor Capua's Honours trampled in the duſt —

sp.speaker: 7 Sen.
sp.p: Nor ſhining horrid with involving Flames.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Shall our chaſt Matrons, and our bluſhing Maids,
Our generous Youth, bred up to nobler hopes,
Attempted, ſeiz'd, o'erpow'rd, be tam'd at laſt,
To the inſults of all unnatural Luſts?

sp.speaker: Vib.
sp.p: If there was nothing elſe to undergo —

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: You cannot call it living on ſuch terms.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: If we agree, that Life wou'd be a load,
Not to be Born, with theſe Indignities:
Here is the helping hand to throw it off.
sp.stage: A Servant gives him a Bowl.
sp.l: This Bowl I have reſerv'd to crown the Feaſt.
Hannibal carries Poyſon in a Ring,
Still to be near him in adverſity.
I have prepar'd this cordial Draught for us.
A noble, and preventing remedy:
To free our Bodies from the Puniſhment,
Our Minds from the Reproach, and Infamy,
Our Eyes and Ears, from being Witneſſes
Of all thoſe Cruelties, that are deſign'd.
Contriv'd, reſerv'd, and wait for conquer'd Men.

sp.speaker: Vib.
sp.l: We wonnot rob our Virtue of its Fame,
To think that any here can ſtand in need
Of words, to argue him into a deed,
Of this high conſequence and character.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: We are confirm'd in reaſon, and reſolv'd.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Then thus I offer you deliverance:
And do begin a Health to Liberty.

sp.speaker: 5 Sen.
sp.p: A generous Health, and ſend it round to all.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Fill all the Bowls at once, that we may joyn
In that moſt noble Pledge; let no Man have
Priority, or Place, in this laſt Scene,
But all unite in honour of the deed.

sp.speaker: Vib.
sp.l: Let us unite our Hands, as well as Hearts,
In this great Work: and ſince we are to part,
We'll part like Friends, lockt In a ſtrict embrace.

div.stage: Magius enters as they are in the Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I muſt not be ſhut out. I come to be
Admitted to the gallant Fellowſhip
Of your great Enterprize. I hear you are
Determin'd and reſolv'd.
sp.stage: Servants give each Man a Bowl.
sp.l: Give me a Cup
Among the reſt.

sp.speaker: 5 Sen.
sp.p: 'Tis Poyſon —

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Not to me.
Or if it ſhou'd be ſo, I come to dye.

sp.speaker: 6 Sen.
sp.p: We'll ſhow you then the way.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I'm old, and weak,
And cannot follow faſt, unleſs you ſtay,
To take me with you in your Company.

sp.speaker: 6 Sen.
sp.p: We will.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: I'm ſorry to ſee you reduc'd to dye.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: I'm ſorry to ſee you reduc'd to live.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: That wou'd be poverty of Soul indeed.
'Tis, not ſo poor with me.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: I'm glad of it.

sp.speaker: 6 Sen.
sp.p: Pacuvius has drank his cordial off.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Secure me mine, and then at leiſure, I
Will tell you the particulars at large,
Of what I went about; the Conſuls doom;
And Capua's Fate —
sp.stage: Servant gives Magius a Bowl, they all drink together.
sp.l: But this delivers me.

sp.speaker: 5 Sen.
sp.p: And all of us.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Now we defy the Doom.
Pronounce it in the threatning Conſuls words:
Tho it ſhou'd thunder from the judgment Seat,
It ſhakes not us. We have our Pardon ſeal'd.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I was not ſuffer'd to approach their Camp,
But as a private Perſon, and a Friend.
They utterly refus'd the Priſoners,
Diſdaining to receive 'em, as a Bribe.
And wou'd not hear me upon any terms,
That I cou'd offer; all I cou'd obtain,
Was to inform my ſelf what they deſign'd
To do with us.

sp.speaker: 6 Sen.
sp.p: It muſt be terrible.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Why, Fourſcore Senators are condemn'd to Death.
Three Hundred of our nobleſt Families,
To be diſpers'd into the Latin Towns,
There to remain as Priſoners at large.
Our Treaſure all confiſcated to Rome, our Lands and publick Buildings forfeited:
Capua to be disfranchis'd of her Rights,
Her Liberties, and her chief Citizens:
The Populace by out-cry to be ſold,
Into the ſeveral States of Italy;
And none permitted to inhabit here,
But Slaves made Free, Strangers, and meaneſt Trades:
Never to be incorporated more
In a Community, to have a Voice
In free Election of its Magiſtrates,
But live enthrall'd under the Scourge of Rome.

sp.speaker: Vib.
sp.p: More dreadful far than Fire, or Sword cou'd be.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: It had been Mercy to extirpate quite
The Name, and Memory of Capua.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: As to my ſelf, 'tis true, they offer'd all,
All honourable terms for me, and mine.
But what is Honour, Fortune, when we have
No Friends, no Country, to rejoyce with us?
I cou'd not think of Life after that Loſs,
Therefore came timely to prevent it here.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: O Magius! let me witneſs to the worth,
I always envy'd. We have rivall'd long
For Capua's Love; but this laſt act of yours
Has forc'd me to confeſs it was your due.
Has thrown all emulation ſo behind,
The Honour of the Race is wholly yours.
Had I proceeded with that openeſs,
With that clear Spirit, in my Countries cauſe —

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: May be it had been better for us all.
This is no time for long Confeſſions.
If you have done amiſs, amend it now:
And by the brave example of your Death,
Correct the influence of an ill ſpent Life.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: I've found this eaſie, honeſt way to Death:
The only way, my Friends, to vanquiſh Rome,
To rob her Conſuls of their Triumph here,
And bear our ſelves the palm of Victory.
sp.stage: A Servant whiſpers Pacuvius, and gives him the Paper, that Junius left behind him.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I thank the Gods I have liv'd long enough,
To all the reaſonable ends of Life:
Liv'd to my Friends, my Country, and my Fame:
Have glutted Nature with ſatiety,
Tir'd all her various appetites of change.
And 'twou'd be an unmannerly return,
For my good cheer, and welcome of the Feaſt.
When I have ſat it out, to grudge to riſe.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: We are all ready now to take our leave.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: But one word more, and then I go with you.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: She's Innocent, and well provided for.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: The Dead live after in the memory
Of thoſe alive, ſo to be handed down,
Thro' all the Ages of Poſterity,
As Tryers of their Fame; abhorr'd, or lov'd,
According to their good, or ill, in Life.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: I wou'd be mention'd only in my Death,

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Let it be ſaid of us, we wou'd have dy'd
To ſave our Country; ſince we cou'd not that:
Nothing cou'd tempt us to ſurvive its fate.
Now lay us gently down.

sp.speaker: Vib.
sp.p: What is thy News?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: Our Gates are open'd to the Enemy:
And Capua is no more.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Wou'd it were ſo.
Better be nothing than be miſerable.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Thou com'ſt too late to do us good, or harm,
By any News that thou canſt bring us now.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I pity our poor Friends that ſtay behind.
Our Minds are going to their native home.
And for the earthy part—

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: I've taken care.
When we are honourably laid in Death,
My Clients have their orders to beſtow
Our Bodies on a Funeral Pile, that's rais'd
On purpoſe, to preſerve our laſt remains.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: 'Tis well, now kindle it, and we ſhall mount
Up to the Skies, in the aſpiring Flame,
And live Immortal in a glorious Name,
